PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Fees: Overseas Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned students and staff of the University of Queensland respectfully showeth:
(1) that in 1979 the Liberal Government introduced overseas student fees,
(2) that those fees have been regularly increased since their introduction,
(3) that the financial burden has caused hardship for overseas students studying here, who have limited earning capacity.
We call on this government to review the decision taken to introduce tertiary fees for overseas students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to
Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms.
Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations.
Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development including the moral development of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled: should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Grape Spirit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the 1983 Budget imposition of the excise on grape spirit used in fortifying wine places at risk the future of the fortified wine industry in Australia.
That the requirement to pay the excise within 7 days of the fortification occurring is inequitable.
That the excise will be reflected in increased costs to the consumers of fortified wines of up to 100 per cent and consumer choice will be restricted.
That this will cause reduced fortified wine sales which will result in reduced intake of grapes from grapegrowers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will reconsider their previous decision and either withdraw this tax or modify its method of application and collection.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in-
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRYING INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND PROMOTION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to increase the limits imposed by the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Act 1972 on the amount of levy which may be imposed, on the production and sale of whole milk and butter fat, for the purpose of promoting the sale of dairy products in Australia. The actual amount of levy imposed is set by regulation and is known as the operative rate. The proceeds of the levy are paid into the Dairy Produce Sales Promotion Fund from which the Australian Dairy Corporation draws funds for its domestic promotion activities.

At present the Act provides that the operative rates of levy for promotion purposes may not exceed 12 cents per 100 litres of whole milk and $3 per 100 kg of butter fat. The operative rates are currently at those levels. Earlier this year the Australian Dairy Corporation and the Australian Dairy Farmers' Federation recommended that the maximum limits be increased to 24 cents per 100 L of whole milk produced and to $6 per 100 kg of butter fat produced.

In doing so the Corporation and the Federation argued that with significant falls in returns on the export market and with every prospect of those returns continuing to fall, there should be much more active promotion of Australian dairy produce on the domestic market. The Corporation mentioned cheese as being a particularly suitable candidate for increased domestic sales if it were more extensively promoted.

The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) accepted the recommendations and on 17 June 1983 was pleased to announce the Government's decision to present legislation to increase the maximum rates at the earliest opportunity. The result is this Bill. Honourable senators may be interested to know that, since then, the Australian Dairy Corporation has, in accordance with sub-sections 13 ( 3) and (4) of the Act, recommended to the Minister, after consultation with the Australian Dairy Farmers' Federation, that the operative rates of levy for promotion purposes in respect of whole milk and butter fat be increased to 19 cents per 100 L produced and $4.75 per 100 kg produced respectively.

On the assumption that the recommended operative rates apply on and from 1 November 1983, and based on present projected production figures for 1983-84, total income from the levy for 1983-84 would be in the order of $9.2m. By comparison, last year's income was $6.5m. The industry's view, as I understand it, is that the revenue from increased domestic sales resulting from greater promotion of dairy products will more than offset the cost of the levy to farmers. I stress that the industry itself has requested the increases in the maximum and operative levy rates. I also note that there are no Commonwealth contributions in respect of the levy for domestic promotional purposes and no financial implications in the Bill for the Commonwealth. As for the remaining clause of the Bill, the opportunity is being taken to correct an anomaly in the Act. Paragraph 9 (1) (a) of the Act refers to gallons while the remainder of the Act is in terms of litres. The Bill will correct this minor inconsistency. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY INDUSTRY STABILIZATION LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is twofold. First, it corrects an anomalous situation whereby levy was not payable on the dairy product content of certain mixtures. Secondly, it provides that, under certain circumstances, levy may be refunded in respect of dairy products contained in other products that are exported, thus removing doubts about whether levy could be refunded in those circumstances.

The Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Act 1977 imposes a levy, with certain exceptions, on dairy products defined by the Act produced at a factory. The levy does not have to be paid until the products are sold and is payable by the proprietor of the factory at which the products were produced. The proceeds of the levy are used to finance a dairy produce price stabilization scheme whose purpose is to protect the domestic price structure for leviable products by providing manufacturers with equalized returns from their domestic and export sales of leviable products.

The first of the proposed amendments will ensure the leviability of the buttermilk powder and whole milk powder content of certain products produced by the removal of water from a mixture of buttermilk or whole milk and one or more other substances. Under the revised definitions of buttermilk powder and whole milk powder inserted by clause 3 of the Bill the buttermilk powder or whole milk powder content of such products, provided it comprises at least 25 per cent of the product, will be subject to levy. The proposed amendment will correct the current anomaly that levy is paid when a mixture is made by combining ingredients in their dry state, but not paid on a similar mixture made by combining the ingredients in a liquid state and drying the resulting product. By virtue of sub-clause 3 (2) levy will only be imposed on these products on and from the first day of the month following the month on which the Act receives the Royal Assent. This limitation is necessary as levy payments are calculated on a calendar month basis.

The Act presently provides for levy to be refunded on dairy products that are exported. If the levy were not refunded the export competitiveness of the products would be reduced. Under the Act as it stands, however, it is not possible to refund levy paid on dairy products that are mixed with other substances to produce other products that are exported. Clause 4 of the Bill will correct the situation. Honourable senators will realise, however, that, given the range of products that contain dairy products, it would not be feasible or realistic to provide for refunds of levy in every case. It was therefore considered desirable to place some limits on the circumstances in which a refund of levy will be available.

Proposed sub-sections 6 (3A) and (3B) provide that a refund will be authorised where the percentage of dairy products contained in the product which is to be exported is not less than a percentage set by regulation. Regulations may be made to vary the minimum requirement, but they may not require there to be more than 75 per cent of dairy products in the product. The Act already requires that any regulation being made under this section must be made taking into account any recommendations of the Australian Dairy Corporation, after consultation with the Australian Dairy Industry Advisory Committee. The proposed sub-sections also provide that a refund will not be authorised unless the application for refund is made in respect of a consignment of 15 tonnes or more. The consignment may consist entirely of products containing at least the minimum percentage of dairy products or may also include ordinary dairy products. Sub-clause 4 (2) simply ensures that the amendments concerning refunds only apply prospectively. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

This Bill contains amendments to three Acts, the first of which is the Dairy Produce Act 1924. That Act establishes the Australian Dairy Corporation and also contains the legislative framework for the dairy products export return pooling scheme. The other Acts affected by the Bill are the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act 1977 and the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Collection Act 1972. These Acts contain the administrative procedures for collecting, disbursing and accounting for receipts under the Dairy Industry Stabilization Levy Act 1977 and the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Act 1972 respectively. I have explained the purposes of these Acts in my earlier second reading speeches on amendments to the Acts.

The amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1924 are intended to bring up to date the Corporation's powers over contracts for the carriage of dairy products by sea to places beyond Australia, to provide a legislative basis for the manner in which the Corporation administers certain provisions of the export return pooling scheme and to make other minor adjustments to the scheme, to require the Corporation to credit any surplus or debit any deficit incurred by it in respect of its export sales of dairy produce to accounts maintained under the export return pooling scheme, and to bring into line with current levels the penalties for offences under the Act.

The first clause of note is clause 4. This clause substitutes a new section 19 dealing with conditions relating to contracts for the shipment of dairy produce overseas. Under the existing section 19 it was necessary either for the Corporation to determine conditions relating to contracts for the shipment of dairy produce or for such contracts to be made only by the Corporation on behalf of exporters.

It recently came to attention that the Corporation had not approved any conditions, yet exporters were entering contracts directly, not through the Corporation. The Corporation indicated that it did not wish, at this stage, to involve itself in the making of shipping contracts. As the Corporation might, at a later date, need to be able to impose conditions, for example in relation to freight rates as part of an agreement with a shipping conference, it was decided that a revised section 19 providing the Corporation with discretionary powers in relation to shipping contracts should be inserted in the Act, rather than simply repealing the existing section 19.

Accordingly, proposed sub-section 19 (1) provides that the Corporation may approve conditions relating to contracts for the carriage of dairy produce by sea to a place beyond Australia. Proposed paragraph 19 (2) (A) requires the Corporation to officially notify licensees (incidentally, all persons wishing to export prescribed dairy produce from Australia must be licensed to do so by the Corporation) of any such conditions. Proposed paragraph 19 (2) (B) requires licensees to comply with any such conditions while proposed sub-section 19 (3) makes failure to comply with the conditions grounds for revoking a licence to export dairy produce.

Proposed sub-section 19 (4) makes it clear that failure to comply with conditions approved by the Corporation does not mean that a contract so made will be void or unenforceable. This is in direct contrast to the existing section 19 which provides as a sanction for failing to comply with conditions that such contracts are void. Such a sanction has proven not to be effective, and in any event, if relied upon, could have undesirable consequences for the international marketing of dairy products. The new sanction of cancellation of a licence is considered to be more appropriate and effective and is consistent with the approach taken in such provisions in other similar legislation.

Clause 5 of the Bill is concerned with revisions of the export return pooling scheme established by section 20AB of the Act. New sub-sections (4AA) and (4AB) will require more detailed notification arrangements where the assessed export price or the minimum export price is fixed or varied. These prices are part of the mechanism by which the amount that is to be contributed by or paid to the exporter under the export return pooling scheme is determined.

The amendments made to sub-section 20AB (5) by paragraphs 5 (B), (C) and (D) of the Bill will correct an anomaly which arises from the fact that the Act is silent as to pooling requirements at times when an export sale takes place at a price which obtains a return below the minimum return in circumstances where the minimum return exceeds the assessed return. As a result, it is presently possible for an exporter selling at the minimum price to receive a lower net, after contribution to pool, return than an exporter who sells below the minimum price. Current administratively desirable practices of the Australian Dairy Corporation in relation to the export return pooling scheme will be given legislative authority by the amendments effected by paragraph 5 (E) of the Bill.

In essence the amendments will provide, in contrast to the existing legislation which is administratively unworkable, that exporters will receive direct the proceeds of their export sales and will then have to remit to the Corporation any required contribution to the export return pooling scheme. Proposed sub- section 20AB (8A) will facilitate the recovery from exporters of amounts which they are required to pay under the export return pooling scheme but which they have not forwarded to the Corporation at the required time.

Honourable senators may be aware that the Corporation, acting pursuant to the power conferred on it by section 15 of the Dairy Produce Act 1924 to buy and sell dairy produce, is a significant trader in dairy products on the export market.

Clause 6 inserts section 24A into the Act. This section will provide legislative authority for a current, appropriate, practice of the Corporation by requiring it to credit any surplus made by it in a particular financial year as a trader on the export market to accounts kept under the export return pooling scheme. Similarly the section will require the Corporation to debit any deficit incurred by it in a financial year as a trader on the export market to those accounts. The basic requirement will be to credit or debit amounts to pools maintained in the production year to which the exported product relates, that is , if product produced in 1981-82 is sold and exported in 1982-83, any surplus or deficit resulting from the export sale is to be credited to or debited from the appropriate 1981-82 product pool, not the 1982-83 pool.

However, it may not always be appropriate or administratively feasible for the Corporation to carry out the transfer as required. For example, should a deficit occur on a sale of a product produced in 1981-82, but sold in 1983-84, at the time the deficit comes to light insufficient funds may remain in the 1981-82 pool to fully meet the deficit. A mechanism has therefore been included in proposed section 24A whereby the Minister may direct the Corporation to credit or debit surpluses or deficits to the most appropriate production year pool or pools. It should be noted that equity considerations may also influence any such directions as individual manufacturers may not contribute equally to the same export pools each year.

Proposed sub-section 24A (7) provides that in making a decision on this matter the Minister may receive advice from the Corporation which in turn is required to consult with the Australian Dairy Industry Advisory Committee, the body established under the Dairy Produce Act 1924 to advise the Corporation in the performance of its functions or the exercise of its powers.

Proposed sub-section 24A (6) provides for the Corporation to take into account amounts, if any, credited to the export pooling scheme as a result of its trading activities, the Corporation is regarded as an ordinary exporter for the purposes of the scheme and thus must contribute or receive payments accordingly, in ascertaining whether a surplus has been made by it or a deficit incurred. This provision does not affect costs which would normally be taken into account such as: Ordinary costs associated with exporting such as storage, insurance and shipping costs; and payments to producers in the nature of premiums in respect of dairy products which the Corporation purchases made pursuant to sub-section 20AB (4A).

Clause 8 inserts a new section 8A into the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act 1977. The proposed section provides explicit legal standing for an already established procedure by requiring proprietors of factories who obtain a refund of levy to pass on the benefit to the exporter. The background to the provision is that the price paid for leviable dairy products takes into account the amount of levy payable on those products, including where the purchaser intends to export the products rather than sell them on the domestic market. Where a leviable product is sold on the export market it is appropriate to refund the levy and the person who is legally entitled to the refund is the person who has paid the levy. However, if exporters did not in turn receive the benefit of this amount they would be obliged to pass on the cost in their prices and the export competitiveness of the products concerned would be reduced accordingly. This amendment will ensure that this does not occur.

The amendments to section 21 of the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act 1977 made by clause 10 and those to section 10 of the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Collection Act 1972 made by clause 15 insert a standard provision requiring warrants to contain a date on which they will cease to have effect and omit the offence of obstructing an officer in the course of his duty as the offence is adequately covered by section 76 of the Crimes Act 1914.

Clauses 7, 12 and 17 provide for the revision, in accordance with current standards, of penalties for offences under the Dairy Produce Act 1924, the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act 1977 and the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Collection Act 1972 respectively.

Clause 14 brings up to date section 7 of the Dairying Industry Research and Promotion Levy Collection Act 1972 by increasing the amount of penalty for late payment of levy that may be remitted by an authorised person from $10 to $100. Clause 16 provides that an appeal from a decision to refuse to remit an amount of penalty may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and inserts a provision requiring notice of appeal rights to be given at the time the original decision is notified.

Clause 11 inserts a similar appeal provision in section 24A of the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act 1977, which will apply to section 6, the section in that Act dealing with penalty payments and their remission. It is worth noting that an appeal will lie not only from a decision of an authorised person, but also from a decision of the Minister, who is authorised to remit any amount of penalty. Clause 11 also inserts a notification of appeal rights provision in relation to the existing appeal mechanism applying to determination of production quotas under section 11A of the Dairy Industry Stabilization Act 1977 .

I point out that the amendments contained in this Bill have no direct financial implications for the Commonwealth. The proposed section 24A of the Dairy Produce Act 1924 concerning the transfer of surpluses and deficits resulting from the Corporation's trading activities to relevant export pools will have implications for the dairy industry. It is not possible to quantify that impact as it will depend on future surpluses or deficits resulting from the Corporation's trading activities. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

This Bill continues the practice developed during the last Parliament of introducing an omnibus Bill into each sittings of the Parliament to make a large number of non-contentious amendments. In introducing the omnibus Bill in the last sittings I informed the Senate of the criteria that had been approved for determining whether a proposed amendment might be included in such a Bill. The following supplementary statement explains in detail the changes to the various Acts which are to be made by this Bill, but does not include minor amendments of a drafting nature:
Supplement to Second Reading Speech
Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975

The purpose of this amendment is to make it clear that part-time members of the AAT do not have the entitlement to a pension under the Judges Pensions Act 1968 which section 18 confers on presidential members of the AAT.
Airports (Surface Traffic) Act 1960

The existing penalty for illegal parking at Commonwealth airports was set in 1976. That penalty is inadequate having regard to present day money levels and does not serve as a deterrent. Moreover, the present level of penalty no longer allows for economic recovery of the costs of pursuing unpaid parking infringement notices.
Australia-Japan Foundation Act 1976

The purpose of the amendments is to provide standard provisions relating to disclosure of possible conflicts of interest by statutory officeholders. The amendments accord with the recommendations of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry Concerning Public Duty and Private Interest.
A similar amendment has been proposed to the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research Act 1982.

Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 The first substantive amendment makes it clear that the Chairman of the Board of the Corporation ceases to hold office as Chairman if he ceases to hold office as a Director. The other substantive amendment requires the Principal Community Affairs Officer to inform a complainant of his decision made on the investigation of a complaint.
Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933

The proposed amendment is intended to remove restrictions (now contained in sub -section 35 (1) of the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act) on the functions that may be conferred on the Registrar of the A.C.T. Supreme Court, and on the means by which such functions may be conferred. In particular, it will permit Ordinances to confer functions on the Registrar which are not in respect of proceedings pending in the Supreme Court.
There are many instances where it is highly desirable for functions, related to the Court's responsibilities but not necessarily to pending proceedings, to be conferred on the Registrar.
Australian Federal Police Act 1979

The proposed amendments to this Act are necessary to ensure consistency with the amendments made to section 36 of the Act by the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) 1983 to ensure that in the selection of members of the Australian Federal Police for promotion to a vacancy within a rank, and in cases where particular expertise or qualification is required, consideration may be given to an applicant's possession of those requirements.
Broadcasting and Television Act 1942

The purpose of these amendments is to remove unnecessary conditions imposed on the application for a Community Television Aerial System licence, to improve certain administrative procedures of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and to remove unintended restrictions on test permits.

Section 83 requires a licensee of a Community Television Aerial System (CTAS) to provide a detailed program undertaking at the grant or renewal of a licence. That requirement is unnecessary as CTAS licences only permit the retransmission of programs originated by other stations. The proposed amendment will remove that requirement and make the provisions of CTAS licences consistent with the analogous translator licences.

Under sections 90J and 92F the Chairman of the Tribunal is required to personally undertake certain functions. The proposed amendments of sections 90J and 92F will permit the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to delegate to other members of the tribunal his authority to accept an application for a share transaction. The amendment will also provide the Tribunal with the discretion to extend the deadline for lodgement with the Tribunal of an application for a change in ownership in the shareholdings of a licensee. The provision of a discretionary extension of the deadline is necessary as the existing time limit of 28 days has proved to short for persons acquiring shareholdings indirectly and places such persons in breach of the Act.

Sub-section 126 (6) of the Act prohibits the holder of a permit for test transmissions from broadcasting or televising advertisements. The purpose of the proposed amendment is to allow the transmission of advertisements by permit holders in certain instances, including where a permit has been granted in relation to a proposed broadcasting translator station licence or a proposed television translator station licence.
Commonwealth Legal Aid Act 1977

The Commonwealth Legal Aid Council ascertains and reviews the need for legal assistance in respect of Commonwealth matters and advises and makes recommendations to the Attorney-General on the most effective and economical means of satisfying that need.

Community legal centres are involved in the provision of legal aid services, advice, referral and research. The Centres are staffed by both volunteer and salaried staff and are managed by members of the community in which they operate . In 1983, thirty-two Centres throughout Australia are receiving grants from the Government. The proposed amendment will make provision for the appointment of an additional member of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council who is representative of community legal centres.
Copyright Act 1968
The Bill includes provisions which amend the Copyright Act 1968 to rectify technical drafting defects which have come to light since the Copyright Act was amended in 1980.

The most significant amendment is to s. 133 which contains penalty provisions for the offences of piracy of copyright material. The effect of the amendment is to make it clear that the penalty provisions apply to piracy of sound recordings , broadcasts and published editions. The application of these was rendered uncertain when special penalties were included in the 1980 amendments to deal with piracy of cinematograph films.
Crimes Act 1914

Section 21AA of the Crimes Act 1914 deals with the power of courts when sentencing a Federal offender to take into account, in certain circumstances, other offences in respect of which an offender has admitted his guilt but not been sentenced. The section is being amended to bring it into line with recently amended provisions of the Judiciary Act 1903. A court will then be able to take into account indictable offences committed outside the jurisdiction if the court would have had power to sentence the offender in respect of that offence pursuant of section 68 of the Judiciary Act 1903.
Economic Planning Advisory Council Act 1983

The Economic Planning Advisory Council, known as EPAC, was set up by the Government to continue the process of consultation and co-operation begun at the National Economic Summit in April this year. EPAC's central purpose is to provide independent, community-based advice to the Government on the broad conduct of economic policy, particularly in a medium and longer-term context. EPAC has at present a membership of seventeen, drawn from the Commonwealth and State Governments, industry, the union movement, local government and community groups. There is, however, no specific provision for the appointment of a member drawn from the small business sector. In view of the importance of that sector in the Australian economy, the Government believes that there would be great value in having on EPAC a member with special knowledge of the problems faced by small businesses. The proposed amendment would allow such an appointment to be made.
Environment Protection (Northern Territory Supreme Court) Act 1978

This is a consequential amendment on the abolition by the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in 1980 of the 'Territory Parks and Wildlife Commission' and its replacement with 'The Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory' .
Evidence Act 1905

Section 4 of the Evidence Act provides that all courts shall take judicial notice of the official signature and seal of any person who holds, or has held, any office to which the Governor-General, by order published in the Gazette, declares the section to apply where the signature or seal purports to be attached or appended to an official document. The section also provides for judicial notice to be taken of the fact that such a person holds, or has held, the office concerned.

It has been the practice to publish the Governor-General's orders from time to time as the need arises. It has also been the practice when making revised consolidated orders to revoke the previous consolidated order, except in relation to signatures or seals purporting to have been attached or appended before the date of the new order. There are doubts that the section does in fact authorise this procedure because it does not specifically provide for the making of orders for offices which have ceased to exist. It is also doubtful that an order made in relation to an office that ceases to exist after the making of the order, continues to operate. The amendments are designed to overcome these doubts.

Section 6 of the Act provides for the admissibility in evidence in all courts of a copy or extract of a Commonwealth public book or document if it purports to be signed and certified as a true copy or extract by the officer in whose custody the original is entrusted. However, if that officer is served with a subpoena calling on him to produce the original, he must produce the original. The amendment will permit the officer to produce a certified copy or extract, in answer to a subpoena calling for production of the original, but enabling the court to require production of the original to be produced if it thinks fit. The amendment is designed to overcome administrative problems that have been caused when a court has custody of original records admitted in evidence. It will bring the Commonwealth Evidence Act into line with evidence laws of most of the States .

The purpose of the proposed amendment to sub-section 7A (1) is to apply Part IIIA of the Act, which facilitates the admissibility of business records in proceedings in federal courts, to proceedings in courts of the Australian Capital Territory.

Part IIIA was inserted in the Act in 1978 and is based on recommendations of the N.S.W. Law Reform Commission. Provisions dealing with this subject matter are to be found in most States in relation to proceedings in State Courts.
It is highly desirable that parties to proceedings in Australian Capital Territory courts have the benefit of the provisions of Part IIIA of the Act.
Federal Proceedings (Costs) Act 1981

The purpose of the amendment is to overcome inequities which now arise from the operation of the Act. The Act has a statutory limit on the amount payable for costs in respect of any one appeal. Where, as is usually the case, the costs of both parties in an appeal are covered by one certificate, the total costs normally exceed that limit. Usually, in such cases, the costs are apportioned on a pro- rata basis. Each party receives a part payment and of his cost and bears the balance of his costs of the appeal.

This situation is aggravated where a new trial is ordered as a result of a successful appeal. For the purpose of the statutory limit a new trial is presently treated as part of the appeal. The one amount must therefore cover two proceedings.

The proposed amendment provides that the prescribed maximum amount payable under the Act applies separately to each costs certificate granted in respect of an appeal, or of a new trial, rather than to the sum of all the costs certificates granted in respect of the appeal, including a new trial.
Growth Centres (Financial Assistance) Act 1973
Land Commission (Financial Assistance) Act 1973

The insertion of a new sub-section 10 (5A) in these Acts will allow the Commonwealth and a State to vary, by agreement, the terms and conditions in relation to the repayment of loans made by the Commonwealth under the Acts. At present the only variation of a loan agreement allowable is in relation to the period of repayment of the loan-sub-section 10 (4).
Judiciary Act 1903.

There are a number of amendments to this Act. The first amendment inserts a new section 39B into the Act. Paragraph 75 (v) of the Constitution confers original jurisdiction on the High Court in matters in which a writ of mandamus or prohibition or an injunction is sought against an officer of the Commonwealth.

The High Court has a heavy workload and one way of reducing that workload would be to confer jurisdiction in paragraph 75 (v) matters on the Federal Court. The High Court cannot be divested of its jurisdiction in this area.

Section 44 of this Act empowers the High Court to remit matters pending before it to any federal court, or court of a State or Territory where that court has jurisdiction in respect of the subject matter and the parties.

The proposed amendment will not only confer jurisdiction so that proceedings under paragraph 75 (v) may be commenced in the Federal Court but will also allow the High Court to remit to the Federal Court matters commenced before it.

The proposed amendment will also close in part a gap which has been left by section 9 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. Section 9 has had the effect of depriving State courts of some jurisdiction which those courts formerly possessed to review decisions and actions of officers of the Commonwealth. But the whole of the jurisdiction so taken away was not conferred on the Federal Court under that Act. As a consequence some parties who might formerly have obtained relief in a State court were confined to seeking relief only in the High Court. Following the amendment they will be able to seek relief also in the Federal Court.

The Federal Court will not initially have jurisdiction under the proposed new legislation in relation to matters arising before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Public Service Arbitrator, the Coal Industry Tribunal or the Family Court of Australia. However, further consideration is being given to extending the capacity of the High Court to remit matters under section 44 in relation to these areas.

Under section 40 of the Act, the Commonwealth and States are each able to apply for removal into the High Court, as of course, of a proceeding involving a constitutional issue. Under section 78A of the Act, the Commonwealth and the States are each able to intervene in such a proceeding. The Northern Territory also should have these rights which would be consistent with self-government. The proposed amendments of those sections will achieve that result.

The purpose of the amendment to section 44 of the Act is to enable the High Court to remit part of any matter that is at any time pending in the Court to any federal, state or territory court that has jurisdiction with respect to the subject-matter and the parties. At present the High Court is only empowered to remit the whole matter. This is an unnecessary restriction on the Court's power, as the High Court should be able to remit any aspect of proceedings which can more appropriately be dealt with by another court, e.g. hearing evidence. The amendment has the support of the Chief Justice of the High Court.

The proposed amendment of section 78B will achieve improved operation of that section of the Act, which provides for Commonwealth and State Attorneys-General to be given notice of proceedings in which a constitutional issue is involved with a view to their considering intervening in the proceedings or removing them into the High Court. It will also put the Northern Territory on an equal footing with the States as regards receipt of such notices.

A new section 88 is to be inserted allowing the making of regulations necessary or convenient to be prescribed under the Act, the content and form of notices under section 78B, the practice and procedure for the giving of notice and specifying any affidavits that are necessary to be attached to section 78B.
Law Officers Act 1964

The Law Officers Act is being amended to include a provision (section 16A), enabling the Solicitor-General to be paid in lieu of long leave. Commonwealth employees have had entitlement to long service leave since 1943 and the legislation provides for payment in lieu of taking long service leave. The provisions were revised in the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1976. Sub-section 10 (3) of that Act excludes from the operation of the Act holders of judicial office and the Solicitor-General. Since the 1960s judges have had, by administrative arrangement, entitlement to long leave and to payment in lieu where that leave was not taken. In 1979 payment in lieu of long leave was put on a statutory basis for High Court Justices and judges of federal courts. Unfortunately, at that time a similar provision for the Solicitor- General was not addressed, which only became apparent earlier this year when the Solicitor-General informed me of his intention to retire later this year.

Under the 1968 amendments of the Law Officers Act 1964 the Solicitor-General has been entitled since that time to payment of pension in respect of his period of service on an equivalent basis to the entitlement for judges of federal courts. In 1980 the Solicitor-General's salary and allowances were increased to the same level as was paid to judges of the Federal Court of Australia. These movements in the Solicitor-General's entitlements demonstrate a clear intention to equate the Solicitor-General with the status of a judge of the Federal Court and the proposed amendment will give effect to that position in relation to payment in lieu of long leave.

Sub-section 17 (2) of the Act is being amended to enable delegation of my powers and functions to officers of my Department other than the Secretary as at present. It will take a considerable load off my personal functions and also those of the Secretary in relation to many minor matters of administration which do not require my personal attention, or even the attention of the Secretary, e. g. the appointment under section 44A of the Trade Practices Act of a person to act as Deputy Registrar of the Trade Practices Tribunal whilst the Deputy Registrar is absent from duty.
Law Reform Commission Act 1973
The proposed amendment of section 12 (3) of this Act will clarify that the Chairman may perform duties as a judge of the Federal Court notwithstanding that his office as Chairman is full-time.
Meat Inspection Arrangements Act 1964
The transfer of the NSW Meat Inspection Service to the Commonwealth was effected on 1 July 1983 under the Meat Inspection Arrangements Act 1964.

Under the arrangement meat inspectors previously employed by NSW were transferred to the Australian Public Service. Such transfers are now effected under the Public Service Act 1922, and the proposed amendments under consideration take account of that fact.

The proposed amendment extending the application of the Act to the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island takes account of the fact that at some future date the Commonwealth may enter into such an arrangement with either Territory.
Pig Industry Research Act 1971 and Pig Meat Promotion Act 1975

The purpose of the amendment to each Act is to include the changed name of the federal pig industry organisation, by substituting Australian Pork Producers' Federation for Australian Commercial Pig Producers' Federation.
Nitrogenous Fertilizers Subsidy Act 1966

The purpose of the amendments is to update the anti-dumping provisions in the Act to reflect the corresponding provisions in the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975. In 1981 amendments were made to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act to change the anti-dumping criteria. Consequently, the anti-dumping provisions in the Nitrogenous Subsidy Act are in conflict with the provisions in the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. The amendment will remove the inconsistencies between the Acts.
Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946

The proposed amendments to sections 13, 23 and 31 of the Act grant the Minister power with respect to certain matters which at present are exercised by the Governor-General. These powers are the appointment of Acting Commissioners, of the Chairman of the Promotions Appeal Board and the Chairman of the Disciplinary Appeal Board. It is felt that the nature of these powers makes them more suitable for exercise by the Minister.

Since 1946 sub-section 75 (2) of the Act has imposed a requirement to consult with an advisory body comprised of representatives of all the British Commonwealth Governments, known as the Commonwealth Telecommunications Council, prior to certain action being taken by the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, e.g. changes in rates of services or discontinuance of services. These provisions were first enacted to enable the introduction of new international telecommunications arrangements between countries of the British Commonwealth. The requirement to consult the Council is being repealed by this Bill. A new arrangement for collaborative financial arrangements has been entered into under which there is neither common use by Commonwealth ''Partners' ' of one another's external telecommunications facilities, nor sharing of the operating expenses of those facilities.
Patents Act 1952

The amendments to this Act remedy difficulties that have arisen under the recently expanded range of activities and services by the Patents Office. These involve the handling of international applications under the Patent Co-operation Treaty and the provision of more ready access to information contained in patents specifications.

The Treaty now provides simplified procedures for obtaining patent protection in a number of different countries. Since its implementation in early 1980 a number of problems have arisen in Patent Office procedures, in the determination of priority dates and in the provision of searches and examination reports. These are overcome by amendments of section 58, 58C and 58F.
To facilitate access to the valuable technical information contained in patents specifications, the amendments to section 35 require the preparation of an abstract.
Royal Commissions Act 1902

The proposed amendments to the Royal Commissions Act permit a Royal Commission to communicate information or furnish evidence or a document acquired by it to another Royal Commission where it appears to the first Royal Commission that the information, evidence or document is relevant to the matters into which the second Royal Commission is authorised to inquire.
Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act (No. 1) 1982

The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act (No. 1) 1982 distinguishes the powers of presidential members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal who are judges of the Federal Court of Australia from other presidential members. By virtue of section 40 of the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act (No. 1) 1982 certain powers required to be exercised by a presidential member can only be exercised by a presidential member who is a Judge of the Federal Court. Included in this requirement is the jurisdiction of the Tribunal under section 66E of the Migration Act 1958.

Following upon the recent recommendation of the Administrative Review Council that any presidential member should be able to constitute the Tribunal for the purposes of hearing applications for review under the Migration Act, the proposed amendment will now permit presidential members who are not necessarily Judges of the Federal Court to hear applications pursuant to the Migration Act. The President of the Tribunal is in agreement with this approach.
Telecommunications Act 1975

The amendments relating to the appointment of an Acting Managing Director or part-time Commissioner do not involve any substantive changes but bring these provisions up to date in accordance with current drafting practice.

The Bill introduces legislation which will lower the minimum retiring age for employees of Telecom Australia from age 60 to age 55 enabling staff to retire early, although with reduced superannuation entitlements. The legislation extends to staff of Telecom Australia early retirement conditions that are available to staff employed under the Public Service Act and the staff of prescribed authorities under the Commonwealth Employees (Re-deployment and Retirement) Act.

Telecom Australia will be given the same flexibility with respect to meetings as those enjoyed by the Parliament House Construction Authority under its legislation. This means that in certain cases meetings will be able to be held and decisions made without all the members being physically present together.
