SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Committee has reached the stage where, after a debate ranging over a period of six or eight weeks in this Parliament, it is concluding its consideration of amendments to the Family Law Amendment Bill. In all of that time not one of the amendments designed to give genuine legislative support to the institution of marriage has been adopted. The Government amendments on the other hand have, by and large, been directed at post divorce situations and to strengthening the powers of the Family Court of Australia. One aspect of the legislation-that relating to divorce by post, which was passed yesterday-has undermined, in the educative sense at least, support for the institution of marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: My proposal attempts to provide an opportunity, and indeed an incentive, for persons who separate to have the benefit of marriage counselling, separately and together, at a very early stage. I have moved amendments to section 15 of the Principal Act which, if passed, would enable a notification to be lodged by a separating party with the Family Law Court. Upon receipt of that application the Principal Director of Court Counselling, within 14 days of the filing of the notice, will send a notice to each of the parties to the marriage calling them, separately, to an interview with the marriage counsellor and to a conference, together, with that marriage counsellor for the purpose of considering the legal , social and financial consequences of a dissolution of marriage and, in particular, the effects of a dissolution of the marriage on any children of the marriage. Having regard to the consequences and effects of such action, a reconciliation is then to be considered.

I also propose amendments to section 44 which would in effect prevent the Family Law Court from hearing a subsequent application for dissolution of marriage unless one party to the marriage has filed a notice of separation and a period of not less than 12 months has lapsed since the filing of that notice and marriage counselling has taken place. Of course, I have included a provision that where in special circumstances the Court considers that this is not appropriate, those provisions will not need to be observed. Senator Missen's major objection appeared to be about special circumstances. Yesterday he apparently--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a minor objection.
—He made a big deal about it yesterday. He apparently was not aware that we had already passed--
—I have not made a big deal of anything.
—He did not know that we had already adopted the proposition of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans).
—It was in the Act.
—Of course it was in the Act. Why did he make a big deal of it ? It was proven to be a red herring.
—If you will listen for a moment, it was because of the fact--
—Senator Missen will have his chance. He can get up and say--
—Senator Harradine, please address your remarks through the Chair.

—That is the quality of the opposition to this amendment. The amendment seeks to do three things. It seeks to overcome the problems which were considered to be inherent in my previous amendment, which this replaces. They are listed in the document which I circulated. The success of my previous amendment was considered to be questionable given that it provided that counselling could take place after the application for dissolution had been filed. Of course, this amendment provides that counselling would take place as soon as possible after the separation. Arrangements for reconciliation counselling must be made within 14 days of the notification of the separation. The second problem with the previous amendment related to the fact that the possibility of reconciliation diminishes the longer a couple is separated. Quite obviously I have in this amendment catered for that objection. The third problem of my previous amendment was that it confused conciliation with reconciliation. Of course I have covered that problem because clearly this amendment refers to reconciliation.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, after this long period we have come to the situation where the Committee has this last opportunity of doing something practical about the real problems, of doing something practical to get reconciliation into the process. It is done against the backdrop of the new figures that have just been released by the Institute of Family Studies, which show that 40 per cent of new marriages will end in failure on 1982 divorce rate figures. The tragic divorce statistics and the problems of stress and anguish that are behind those statistics must be of concern to even the most hard-hearted. Last year the figures of divorce in Australia increased by 48,088. Children directly affected by divorce last year numbered over 53,000, bringing to almost 400,000 the number of children affected by divorce since the Family Law Act of 1975. These, for the most part, have been the unwilling characters in the divorce scene. In the words of the authenticated United States survey, which was reported in the Institute of Family Studies newsletter, more than three-quarters of the children opposed divorce very strongly and many refused to believe it.

However, in addition to the cost of divorce in non-material terms, to those directly affected and to society as a whole there is also the cost to the taxpayer. The principal reason of opposition by the Attorney-General to this measure is on the ground of what it would cost. Apart from the enormous cost of the Federal Court of Australia apparatus-I have the documents here relating to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1983-84 and the estimates for the Attorney-General's Department-and apart from the enormous cost in Australian legal aid for these cases, let us look at the other costs to the community of divorce in Australia so that we can counterbalance the Attorney-General's opposition to this proposition on the grounds of cost. Since 1975 the number of divorcees receiving the widow's pension has increased by 174 per cent. In 1982, $717.4m was paid out in widow's pension and well over half of those receiving the widow's pension were divorcees or separated wives. Again, almost 70 per cent of those receiving the supporting parents benefit, at a cost in 1982 of $605.9m, are separated wives or de facto wives, which is an increase of more than 300 per cent since 1975.

There are very few people in the community who would begrudge the payment of this money, particularly after all the tribulations many of those people have experienced, but the financial as well as other consequences of divorce must be realised. The Federal Government has made some comment about getting tough with maintenance collections, but that is not enough. It does not go to the heart of the problem. Some of us, over the long time that this debate has been ranging, have attempted to amend the Family Law Act to give genuine legislative support to the institution of marriage. After all, as I have mentioned previously, section 46 of the Marriage Act 1961 requires the authorised celebrant during the marriage ceremony to remind the couple of the:
. . . solemn and binding nature of the relationship into which you are now about to enter.
Marriage, according to law in Australia, is the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life.

It is a strange parliament indeed which gives lip service to the institution of marriage but refuses to give it genuine support. It is, after all, the basic institution of society. Not one member of the Government has chosen to consider this issue to be a conscience matter, and I will deal with that later.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or any other amendment.

—No, that is not correct, I think. If cost is the only coherent argument put forward by the Government against this measure, it must be weighed against the enormous cost of divorce in material terms, let alone non- material terms. To those who have not been prepared to accept amendments which go to the heart of the matter, which attempt to give legislative support to the institution of marriage, I say that this is their opportunity to do so. Even those who are indissolubly wedded to the no fault divorce system should realise that this proposal for reconciliation counselling lends itself to a trial. As has been suggested, I think by Senator Walters, let it be a sunset trial if you like, but it is surely entitled to a trial. After all, if there is no fault divorce the notification of separation does not need to contain details of the problems of the marital breakdown. It gives the marriage counsellor a free chance, an opportunity to attempt reconciliation. After all, if we do it in a number of other matters such as industrial relations why not for the basic institution of marriage?

—Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. With great respect I say that you have an enormous responsibility today. Sixty senators or more have given up important appointments in their electorates and important meetings to have an additional sitting day for the Senate so that we can undertake and get through Government business. I did not interrupt the speech of Senator Harradine out of courtesy. However, if, simply because we are on air, we are to have honourable senators re-reading their second reading speeches on this matter throughout the course of the day, honourable senators who have spoken identically several times before on this Bill, using these amendments as an excuse to reiterate their views on marriage and divorce, I for one would be quite resentful of what I would regard as an abuse of the acquiesence of senators in sitting an additional day to assist the Government in the conduct of its business.
—Mr Chairman--

—Senator Harradine, I do not need any assistance on this point of order. I am watching the proceedings closely. Senator Harradine's remarks were relevant to his amendment. I will, of course, rule out of order any tedious repetition or irrelevancy, but Senator Harradine's remarks were in order.

—I have been following closely the debate on Senator Harradine's proposed amendment. I suppose that many honourable senators who have not supported Senator Harradine have nevertheless a very great interest in the preservation of marriage. Some of them are as concerned as Senator Harradine, but I think it is proper that we submit every proposed amendment to critical analysis because there may be problems with amendments. I am attracted to the idea of reconciliation counselling taking place between the time a marriage is in difficulty and the time it is dissolved. If we could move to encourage reconciliation and perhaps save even one marriage, even every now and then, society would be the winner. That is the point that Senator Harradine has been trying to make. I do not think that any honourable senator present would disagree with that. But it is correct that we examine some of the problems that the amendment seems to propose. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has raised some valid problems. I am concerned that the counselling should be mandatory. I am concerned about the logistic and resource problems mentioned by the Attorney-General. I am particularly concerned about the objections which the Attorney-General has reported from all the organisations which are involved in counselling.
—That was on a previous amendment, though.
—Perhaps the Attorney-General will answer that interjection.
—The objections are to compulsion.

—I am trying, in good will, to raise some of the things that would worry people who are interested in reconciliation but who are not necessarily convinced that what is being proposed will be either practicable or effective. I have one more concern which I do not believe has come out in the discussion so far. As I understand it, a person can file for dissolution of marriage 12 months after the couple has separated. Unless I am mistaken, Senator Harradine's amendment would have the effect of lengthening that period, because people would not be able to have a dissolution of marriage until 12 months after the counselling was complete.
—No.
—As I read the amendment, it said that it was 12 months after people got the certificate to say that the reconciliation process had been in effect.
—No.

—Some honourable senators are shaking their heads. Perhaps they will explain why that is not so. As I read the amendment as it was proposed , I thought that it would have the effect of prolonging the period for the couple.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intervene only briefly and really because of the intervention of Senator Chipp. I just wish to say that one of the reasons that the Opposition agreed to sit extra time was that there were difficult items of legislation such as this which have always been very time consuming. Initially it was suggested that the whole of Fridays would be devoted to legislation of this sort, which tends to attract the interest of some honourable senators who have very passionate views on the subjects raised. For many of us who have a great interest in the subject matter of this legislation, the fact that others are putting the views that we believe need to be put is the reason why we are not intervening in the debate further. Indeed, on occasions Senator Harradine has put views which I think badly needed to be put in this place. Had he not put them, I might have felt constrained to enter into the debate more often myself.

SPEECH.PARA: The last thing I want to say is that the significance of the item we are debating is very great. It is significant in a number of ways. We are trying to find the appropriate mechanism which will do most to minimise marital breakdown. That is a matter which is important not just in a narrow sense because of the personal interests of parties. The fact is that there are two significant groups of Australians living in poverty in 1983. They are drawn from the ranks of the unemployed and they are drawn from the ranks of single supporting parents, and the bulk of those come from broken marriages. So there are very great social implications in the area with which we are dealing. I am grateful to those honourable senators who are probing the different propositions which are being put forward in Committee debate. I doubt that we shall debate anything more important during this session. In response to Senator Chipp, I would just ask him to be tolerant of the views of those who see this matter as being of central importance to Australia in 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the emotions involved in a subject such as this, the debate has been conducted with a good degree of calm and constructive endeavour on all sides of the chamber. It is certainly not the Government's desire to cut short or terminate the debate in any way, even at this late stage. We would, however, share Senator Chipp's hope that we could avoid any further repetition of any arguments at this stage and that is a stricture that I apply to myself as much as to anyone else in the Chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just quickly pull together the threads that seem to be left over. I think Senator Peter Baume's contribution stood on its own feet, quite irrespective of the misunderstanding that I think he was under in the latter part of his speech. He did, I think, misrepresent Senator Harradine's proposal to the extent that he suggested it would have implications for stretching out the time that would be needed to be taken before dissolution proceedings could be set in train. Senator Harradine's proposal, as I understand it, is simply this: After a notice of separation is filed, counselling must take place some time between then and when the notice of dissolution is filed, but cannot take place for 12 months after the notice of separation is filed. So as long as it is some time within that 12 months period, there is no stopping of the clock, as it were, before people can in fact set in train the dissolution proceedings. Maybe that will make unnecessary any further intervention in the debate by Senator Harradine, but I am not sure.

As to Senator Harradine's contribution this morning, might I simply pull the answers together quickly by saying this: Although his amendment is manifestly well intentioned, and I sympathise profoundly with the objectives which lie behind it, the difficulty with it is that he is unable, in the nature of things, to provide any evidence that his proposal will produce any significant results by way of better reconciliations of marriages in the process of breaking down. Indeed, all the available evidence is very much to the opposite effect. The plain fact of the matter is that the experts, the marriage counselling organisations, some 20 organisations, with which we consulted specifically on this point-in the context, true, of the previous amendment-do not, any of them, wish to be involved in compulsory counselling of any kind. The only organisation that has stated a different view is the Catholic Family Welfare Bureau of Canberra and that is an organisation which has had not one single section 14 (6) referral from the court to give it an experience of a compulsory counselling situation. All the other organisations we consulted have had substantial experience of section 14 (6) compulsory counselling and say: 'It is all counter- productive. It does not help. For God's sake, do not vest us with this responsibility'. Similarly, the Family Court counsellors are wholly opposed to compulsory counselling of any kind, and they should know, just as the marriage counselling organisations should know. Compulsory counselling is, for all intents and purposes, generally and universally unacceptable to those who should know, and it is that element of compulsion which is exactly the same in Senator Harradine's amendment as in the existing section 14 (6) proposal. There are some differences, of course, in the two proposals and it may be that the requirement of counselling in a conference situation, with both parties present, which is a central feature of Senator Harradine's proposal, may make some small difference to the possibility of reconciliation. We do not know. There is simply no evidence available on this point. They are the possible benefits involved in this.

On the other side of any equation that a government must apply are the costs when weighed against the benefits, in this case very dubious benefits, and here the costs are simply enormous. The reality of the matter is that, whether we like it or not, there are over 40,000 dissolutions taking place each year. The counselling involved for those, on a compulsory basis, if this amendment were to go through, would involve three sessions, on Senator Harradine's rule, for each one of those marriages. Thirty thousand counselling sessions would have to be arranged over and above those that are provided for at the moment. Our calculation-and I now have available a detailed breakdown which I did not have yesterday-shows that, if those counselling services were to be provided through the Family Court, the all up cost per annum, not just starting up costs but per annum, would be $26m. It may be less than that if the money were channelled to external organisations. But given the resources and everything else associated with doing it through the Family Court, that is what it would be. Weighed against the wholly speculative benefits, indeed the very dubious benefits, and on the evidence of the marriage counselling organisations, the likely counter- productivity, when it comes to benefits, that sort of cost simply cannot be justified as an experiment to see whether it would work. Might I suggest to Senator Harradine that we do have still in the legislation, as we know-and he can point to the inconsistency and I acknowledge it-a provision for compulsory counselling so far as young or short marriages are concerned, that is, the two year marriages.

We have, in the course of this debate, amended slightly the situation that has been prevailing, to the extent that that counselling has to take place before filing rather than after it, as was previously the situation. It may be that as a result of that we will get some better experience of the way in which that kind of compulsory counselling works.

Certainly we can keep this under review, and certainly we share the aspiration that anything we as a Government, as a society, can do to stop marriages breaking up ought to be done. But in all the circumstances that I have explained , the counter-productivity of compulsion combined with the cost and the resource factor makes this amendment simply unacceptable at this point. I hope, since I am really doing no more than repeating matters that have already been raised in this debate, that we can now proceed to a vote on the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in my room doing something else when I heard the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) start speaking. He said that he did not believe that this provision delayed the introduction of the dissolution proceedings. I believe the wording of the amendment in fact does mean that one cannot file for an application for dissolution until 12 months after the notice of separation is filed.
—But the counselling itself does not delay it. I think that is the misapprehension under which Senator Peter Baume laboured.

—If one can get a divorce within 12 months from the date of separation, that significantly alters the thrust of the Family Law Act. To that extent Senator Peter Baume was absolutely correct in the proposition that he put forward and I think the way the Attorney-General expressed himself was misleading. This amendment, in fact, would be a very significant alteration to that aspect of the Act if it were to be included.

SPEECH.PARA: I am basically in sympathy with what Senator Harradine is talking about. I believe that, even to the extent that compulsion is unacceptable, if it becomes the practice to seek counselling as soon as the crisis is recognised a reconciliation may be achieved in some cases. The separation may even be made a more civilised process than can occur now before people get to any form of counselling. We should try to get them to accept going to a counsellor to seek help at that point, because that is the point where help can be of benefit in making, as I say, even a separation more civilised and in stopping the fighting over children and access at a very early stage. To that extent I am very much in sympathy with what Senator Harradine says. Getting help should become a part of the community concept of marriage-we certainly get help if we have a toothache or appendicitis-but the concept of seeking help with our personal relationships is not well accepted. Paragraph (2) of the amendment proposes that a party to a marriage may file in the Family Court, but the next paragraph proposes that an application for dissolution shall not be filed for 12 months. I would like to support this, and say that the financial costs, if this measure is really worth while, have to be considered as a totally different thing. The way it is now I see as causing absolute chaos and litigation about when the document was filed and the meaning of it. People will have difficulty in understanding it. I am sure the lawyers will be delighted, because the 'may' in the one place and the ' shall' in the other will lead to litigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I clarify any further wreckage I may have caused. I do not want to be unfair either to Senator Harradine in regard to his proposal or to Senator Peter Baume but the situation is that I think I was right in saying that the counselling process itself would not necessarily cause any delay because there is no requirement that time stop running until the counselling process is completed, which I suspect is what Senator Peter Baume thought the proposed section meant. I can understand that reading of it. It certainly does not do that but equally it is true that it introduces a new procedural step that has to be taken which does not exist at the moment, and that is the filing of a notice of separation. Certainly the 12 months needed to establish separation existing before one can file notice of dissolution only starts running from the filing of such a notice, and to the extent that that is a practical matter-people might not file the notice of separation the first time the suitcase is packed-that may mean considerably longer periods elapsing and a degree of confusion as to when time does start to run when it comes to the dissolution stage. But if someone filed the notice of separation at the time the suitcase was first packed it does not necessarily follow, of course, that there would be any additional time factor involved than is the case under the existing law because the 12 months would then start running from the first day of the separation. So in terms of the time implications, it does not necessarily add to it. I think there is some point in what Senator Reid said about the practical implications of this matter and, possibly, a degree of confusion, but I do not honestly think this is anything more than a red herring in the debate. I think the real issues are those that have been articulated by Senator Harradine and, hopefully, by me from the other point of view.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the support in principle given by Senator Margaret Reid. What she said is quite true; if it were to become known that reconciliation counselling is required it would become an acceptable part of the situation. I think Senator Reid said in those short words what perhaps I should have said in introducing this measure. However, she quibbles with the words 'may' and 'shall'. I do not know precisely what else one could have done. One cannot demand that persons who are separating file a notification of that fact with the Family Court of Australia. After all, they might be separating for a number of reasons. They may separate on a mutual understanding.
—They could separate without having a divorce.

—Yes, they could certainly do that. This avenue is open to somebody who may be very confused. It is also open to the other party of the marriage to file the application. But say, for example, the man shoots through on the wife. Very often that is the case. The wife does not know where the husband is, what his intentions are or whatever. The man might be confused. If it is understood very broadly throughout the community that this measure is available to the husband or wife a notification can be made. He may have in the back of his mind the thought that a dissolution of marriage might be sought at some future stage. He will then know that an application for dissolution cannot be filed until 12 months after the filing of a notice of separation. That is an incentive to him to file the notification in the Family Court.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, that is at the very early stages. If the marriage counsellor sees him and the wife separately and has discussions with them together, the marriage counsellor has a real chance of sorting out their confusion. As my amendment states, the counselling is with the parties, both separately and jointly, and in a conference. What will occur? The parties to the marriage will be given counselling to consider the legal, social and financial consequences of a dissolution of marriage and, in particular, the effects of a dissolution on any children of the marriage and, having regard to those consequences, consider a reconciliation. That will focus their minds on the facts of life. So many divorces occur because people drift into divorce.

I am grateful to Senator Reid for raising the point that if it becomes public knowledge that this is the requirement under the law and that an application for dissolution of marriage cannot be filed until 12 months of the filing of the separation notice, required reconciliation counselling of the nature envisaged by my amendment will be accepted without any problems. The problem arises, it appears from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), in regard to administration and cost of the matter. As Senator Reid said, let us not be concerned about that cost if it engenders a community response and attitude conclusive to success. Obviously, some major administrative problems would be involved. There would need to be recruitment and training of skilled counsellors . As has often been said, on the reconciliation side counselling by unskilled and inadequately motivated people is sometimes worse than no counselling at all. I acknowledge that to be a problem, but I come back to the objections that marriage guidance organisations or approved marriage counselling organisations have to my previous proposition. I did not know that I had at least one supporter for my previous proposition. I am glad to hear that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you have to say to that, because these people are in the field, are they not? They say it is not working.
—They said that my previous proposition-
—The compulsion is the same. You have not mentioned the word 'compulsion' once.
—I will read what the psychological counselling section of the Attorney-General's Department said.
—Who?

—The people who have been passing notes to the Attorney- General. I picked up the points they made. They said of my previous proposition that the major resistance to it was to its compulsion. They then went on in relation to clause 7 to explain:

SPEECH.PARA: Almost without exception organisations were influenced by the complete failure of section 14 (6) referrals to produce reconciliation. This section applies to people who seek divorce with less than two years of marriage. The approved organisations which support the amendment had no experience with section 14 (6) referrals.

Presumably, this is the question that the honourable senator is talking about. I had one supporter for my previous proposition, and presumably that is the organisation that did not have section 14 (6) referrals. This is the whole point : We are dealing with experience of section 14 (6) matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a compulsory counselling situation, the best analogy we have.

—This is the only thing you have. Section 14 (6) requires a compulsory interview not with both parties necessarily present but with either of the parties. The other aspect is that the counselling is after the application for a dissolution has been made. That comes into clause 6 of the document, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is generally agreed that once a couple has filed for divorce it is too late for reconciliation.

I agree that the longer a couple is separated, the harder it is to get reconciliation. Quite clearly, that objection was based on the fact that the previous proposition involved counselling after application for disallowance of marriage had been filed. My new amendment picks up that objection also. That is another reason I altered it. The counselling in my proposal now before the Senate will take place not only before the application for dissolution but also, typically, well before-nine to 12 months before.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have picked up one objection, but ignored the central objection.

—The Attorney-General should be fair. He has said that there is a whole range of objections. The objections are based on experience under section 14 (6) and they were valid in regard to my last proposal. The measure that I have put forward is entirely distinct from section 14 (6) because of the reasons I have mentioned.
—Compulsion is still an essential part of your proposal.

—Oh, is that the problem? Compulsion is the nub of the problem , is it? Well, why did the Attorney-General earlier in this debate move a motion for compulsory reconciliation counselling for young married couples? If compulsion is the problem, why did he do that? He also picked up the objection that counselling may be too late if it is done after the application for dissolution of marriage has been filed. The only difference between the legislation now under section 14 (6) and the proposed new clause is that reconciliation counselling will be required before the application is made. My worry about that provision is that it does not pick up the other problems pointed out by marriage counselling organisations; that is, they will say that reconciliation counselling is more successful if one can get both parties together. In retrospect, I think the Attorney-General's amendment to clause 17 will not work because it does not pick up that problem. Will the Attorney- General come into the chamber after two years experience under this provision and say: 'Well, it will not work because it does not take account of what I have said'.
—We can see how it works with a market of 500 cases a year and not commit ourselves to doing 50,000.

—It does not pick up the objections. The other point that was made by Senator Peter Baume-the question of the mandatory nature-has been dealt with. The Committee has already approved it. The Attorney-General voted for that . The objections from organisations are made of straw, because they were on my previous proposition. I have picked up all of the problems that have been raised . I admit that practical problems of cost and administration are involved, and those practical problems are real.
—Do you have any expressions of support for your new proposition from the counselling organisations?
—Yes. I have picked up all of their complaints.
—No, do you have expressions of support from them now?

—No, because I have not distributed my proposal to them. It was printed only on Tuesday of this week. I wrote to honourable senators about it. The final point that was made was that there are practical problems. I acknowledge that there are practical problems-manpower, or people power, problems, and so on. I acknowledge that that is a real problem. Between the time this matter is considered in this chamber and it is considered in the House of Representatives, let us consider how those administrative problems can be overcome. The Attorney-General should have a look at the problems. If there is some support for this proposal in principle, the Government should look at how the administrative problems can be overcome. I believe, as I said before, that if reconciliation processes are mandatory in a range of areas, from industrial relations to sex discrimination, and they work in those areas, why can they not work in this area of human relationships? I ask the Minister to release the members of his Party from their voting obligations on this Government Bill and allow them to have a conscience vote on the issue, so that a genuine vote can take place.
—There is no difficulty about any member of this chamber voting on a free vote basis on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to be very brief. I support, in principle, Senator Harradine's amendment, as I did the original amendment, to strengthen provisions for reconciliation that Senator Harradine moved and we debated on 24 August. The dilemma before us is that most honourable senators do support bona fide attempts towards reconciliation when there are pressures making for difficulty in a marriage. There is provision in the Family Law Act for a judge of the Family Court of Australia at any stage to give consideration to the possibility of a reconciliation of the parties. However, in practice what we have seen in the last eight years is that this has amounted to an empty phrase in the law and there has been no real outcome in terms of reconciliation. One of the reasons for this is that, by the time the matter is before the Court, 12 months have elapsed and the difficulties and divisions between the separated parties have become entrenched. It is particularly inappropriate to have compulsory attempts at reconciliation at that very late stage.
—Not always.

—I do not want to be too distracted because I do not want to take up the time of the Senate. The dilemma is that there is a bona fide wish on the part of most honourable senators that there be attempts at reconciliation. There is provision for reconciliation in this general way in the Act, but in practice this does not come about. However, with regard to marriages that have lasted for less than two years there is, under section 14 (6) of the Act, a direct compulsory provision that the dissolution of a marriage cannot be considered if the parties have not been referred to a marriage counsellor approved by the Court.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine's original amendment, which many of us supported in our remarks on 24 August, was to make the present provision for marriages of less than two years available to all marriages. The objection was then put-it has been repeated here today-that it is too late after 12 months have elapsed for that reconciliation process to work. Therefore Senator Harradine, I believe in very good faith, has put forward this week this revised amendment which would provide for notice of separation at an early stage of difficulty in a marriage and the immediate procedural step of reference to a marriage counsellor. I think that this is a genuine attempt to overcome the objection that the reconciliation process will be ineffective if the 12 months of entrenched separation has occurred before that reconciliation process starts. That is why I support, in principle, Senator Harradine's revised amendment.

The objection to compulsory counselling is acknowledged, I think, by all of us; there will be more likelihood of reconciliation if there are not any elements of compulsion. However, that does not deny that there will be some benefits if there is a direct procedural step in considering the dissolution of a marriage.

That is why I believe that encouragement for reconciliation will give more practical effect to the attempt by all of us in this debate to save marriages. My last remark has only to do with the cost. On behalf of the Government Senator Gareth Evans said that this amendment would cost the Government $26m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Per annum.

—Per annum. If there are 40,000 dissolutions of marriage in any year, that means that the cost to the Government for each marriage dissolved will be $650. I do not know whether the cost of marriage counselling in respect of one marriage in difficulties would amount to $650 in one year.
—That cost would include training the new counsellors, of course.

—Maybe that cost also involves training. I want us to consider what the net recurrent cost is, not the cost of setting up accommodation and the cost of the training of these marriage counsellors. I am very surprised at this costing of $26m. I would find it more reasonable if the figure was about one- sixth of that. I think that a professional marriage counsellor who charged $100 for even lengthy discussions with a couple who were separated or who were seeking marriage counselling would be of some real assistance. The main point I want to make about the cost, even if this estimate is extremely exaggerated, is that that cost ought to be borne by the parties themselves and not by the Family Law Court or by the taxpayer. An analogy was made before with regard to workers compensation or other procedures that require a professional certificate. In those cases the professional costs are borne by the individual involved and not by the government. So I do not see this exaggerated cost as being an impediment to this amendment. Rather, the only argument that bears consideration is the degree of compulsion, which will undermine the effectiveness of the reconciliation process. I agree that there is some substance in that argument, but my conclusion is this: Let us have some practical outcome of all our attempts to see a reconciliation process that is effective and saves marriages. I support Senator Harradine's amendment and commend it to all honourable senators.

—Very briefly, I just wish to say that I think that if this amendment is agreed to by the Committee the clause will need some drafting attention before it becomes operative. I intend to support the amendment because I support the thrust of it. I think that paragraph 2A (b) sets up a litigious potential that ought to be looked at. If the amendment is accepted I believe that this clause ought to be looked at again, perhaps by one of the committees of the Senate, in terms of how it would operate . Perhaps now is not the time to be indulging in drafting on the run.
—I rise very briefly.
—Go on.

—It is a pity Senator Gareth Evans looks pained, because I will only take two minutes. I take that two minutes because I want to raise my sunset clause aspect. It is about the only question he has not answered.
—He did last night.

—He did not mention it last night. This could be an educative process. At the moment it is not the done thing to go to marriage guidance counsellors. People feel a bit ashamed about going. This is a pity. Every counsellor who came before the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act said the same thing. They said: 'We believe that we can do something for people if we can see them early enough'. I am well aware that one cannot legislate to get them early enough unless one legislates for guidance prior to marriage, which we should think about. The situation in future would be that one would not be able to get a divorce unless one seeks counselling. It would work down the line. I believe that in a few years people would be more readily able to face guidance counsellors as soon as the first problem arises in the marriage. It will be accepted in the early stages because it is compulsory. I believe that if the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) asked counsellors a question on this matter they would say the same as they did to the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act.
—They do not. They say the opposite, in fact.

—Senator Zakharov is not listening to the debate at all if that is what she is saying. What the counsellors have said to Senator Gareth Evans-I admit it-is that compulsion at a late stage is no good at all. But to the Committee they said: 'If only we could get these people early, if only we could get them at the first problem in the marriage, we believe we could do something about it'. I believe this compulsion is educative. In a few years time people will be going to the counsellor at an early stage in their marriage problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would hate Senator Walters to go unanswered in any respect in this debate. To the extent that it is desirable to have some kind of experiment to see whether compulsory counselling in some context may not work, might I suggest to her that we do have such an experiment with the revised section 14 (6). Although it is a different model, it is not the same model, at least on the issue of compulsion and on the issue of time-to the extent that it runs now at any time up to the point of filing for divorce rather than, as previously, having to be done only before the dissolution proceedings-we have some basis for getting further and better results as to how this kind of situation might work. I acknowledge all the points of difference Senator Harradine insists upon.

SPEECH.PARA: An experiment involving an average of 500 or so divorces a year is one that is manageable in terms of governmental resources, as compared with one involving 40 ,000 divorces a year. We are talking about nearly $26m a year, whatever the figure is along the way. We just cannot afford to have an experiment of that kind. I hope that will be accepted by Senator Walters as the answer I am giving, whether or not she likes it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans); Will he look at just those marriages that have children? That will reduce the 40,000 divorces considerably. He might be able to manage that sort of thing.
—Just the marriages with children are 60 per cent of the total.
—Well, it has cut it almost in half.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to enter this debate again, but Senator Gareth Evans has forced me to do so.
—I acknowledged all the differences.

—The honourable senator did not. Obviously he does not understand it. Do I have to go over all of his Department's documents? If he likes, I will read it word for word and show what the situation is. This document is the basis for the advice the honourable senator is being given on this matter. If the honourable senator is saying his amendments to proposed new section 44 (1B), relating to young marriages, are going to be a test of the efficiency of compulsory counselling of the type that I envisage, that is absolutely wrong and he knows it. In fact, his amendments are contrary to what is contained in the document prepared by the psychology and counselling section of his own Department. I will quote from page 3. The officer concerned says:

SPEECH.PARA: This all suggests several conclusions that counselling is most likely to result in reconciliation if it takes place prior to, or immediately after separation.

The fact is that I took that suggestion into account. The Attorney-General had not done so. His clause 17, proposed new section 44 (1B), does not pick up another matter referred to by marriage counselling organisations; that is, that both parties should attend counselling separately and together. His proposed new section does not require this. Therefore, there is no validity at all in the suggestion that counselling under his proposal will be the test of the issue; none whatsoever. Indeed on page 3 of that document, the author, Gerald Sanctuary , talks about the experience in Finland. If the Minister wants me to read what Gerald Sanctuary said I will take the time of the Senate to read it. Gerald Sanctuary is dealing with situations which are not no fault divorce situations, where there has already been talk of divorce. A person who is in this situation is already totting up the faults in the other party. This was the very type of situation said by proponents of the no fault divorce to militate against reconciliation. As I said before, anybody who supports the no fault divorce, and I am not, ought to support the proposition that I am putting forward.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Harradine's) be agreed to.
Proposed new clause 16A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will recall that this matter related to a recommendation by the Family Law Council. I previously moved an amendment which was the draft that the Council had prepared and which was defective because it did not fit into the proposed new clause, as it was. Also, Senator Harradine made suggestions that its terms were not wide enough. This amendment relates to a specific desire to have conciliation among the principles that ought to be applied by the Family Court of Australia and other people affected. Reconciliation, which, of course, is covered under the present section 43, is covered in the general meaning of conciliation but the reverse does not apply. There certainly is no reference among the principles to conciliation. Of course we are concerned with conciliation.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I should say something about the history of this amendment. Since the last time we considered this amendment I have had the assistance of the staff of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the parliamentary draftsmen. They have suggested that there should be a separate clause. My previous amendment did not fit very well in section 43. They have prepared proposed new section 43A. I will be moving the amendment standing in my name. It is actually not amendment No. (43). I will be withdrawing amendment No. (43) and moving amendment No. (44) which is the redraft of amendment No. (43). That is a proposed new separate clause which sets out certain procedures not only for the Court but also for other courts and any legal practitioner acting under the provisions of the Act or consulted by a person considering instituting proceedings. The new amendment states that the wide field of people involved in the administration of the Act shall:
. . . have regard to the need to direct the attention of parties to such proceedings and persons considering such proceedings to-

(a) the facilities provided by courts exercising jurisdiction under this Act for counselling to assist parties to marriages and children of marriages to adjust to the consequences of marital breakdown; and
(b) the procedures available for the resolution by conciliation of matters arising in the proceedings.

I put to the Committee that this is a practical and useful way of drawing attention to those facilities. I think part of the problem in the past in cases of breakdowns has been that a great deal of unnecessary trauma has occurred and there has been a lack of knowledge by parties of the counselling they can obtain . The drawing attention to and the use of those facilities means that people will know that they can have the voluntary use of those facilities. I think that particularly for children of the marriage a great deal of unnecessary hardship occurs because of the fact that very often in divorce proceedings the children are used, one person against the other, as a weapon. I believe that the amendment, as redrafted, is sufficiently wide to cover the field. It draws attention to the principles of conciliation which I think are much more likely to have practical operation in reconciliation. No matter what we might wish, at least we must recognise that much can be done to smooth the change and the creation of new families so that the innocent victims of a breakdown do not suffer unnecessarily.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for Senator Missen to withdraw his amendment No. (43) and move as a substitute amendment No. (44)? There being no objection, leave is granted.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (44) Page 12, after clause 16, insert the following new clause: '16A. After section 43 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted: ''43A. The Family Court and any other court exercising jurisdiction under this Act, and any legal practitioner acting in proceedings under this Act or consulted by a person who is considering instituting proceedings under this Act, shall have regard to the need to direct the attention of parties to such proceedings and persons considering such proceedings to- (a) the facilities provided by courts exercising jurisdiction under this Act for counselling to assist parties to marriages and children of marriages to adjust to the consequences of marital breakdown; and (b) the procedures available for the resolution by conciliation of matters arising in the proceedings.''.'.
I thank the Attorney and his staff for the assistance they have given me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -Let us be clear about what we have just done and what we are doing now. Senator Missen has just said that he believes it is more practical to concentrate on conciliation rather than reconciliation.
—No, conciliation-reconciliation is already in the Act.
—Section 43 of the Act deals with it.
—I know what is in the Act. I am about to tell Senator Missen what is in the Act. He did not know yesterday.
—Is that so?

—He obviously did not know what was voted upon. This chamber has just rejected the proposal for reconciliation, a proposal which, on the experience of all other areas of human conflict, would certainly have had some chance of support and some chance of success. Now the concentration is being placed on divorce conciliation. In other words, the attitude is: 'Settle it quickly and no matter what, we will fix up the consequences'. It does not go to the heart of the problem. To add insult to injury, it is to be put in section 43 of the Act as a new section 43A. What does section 43 state?
—It is a new section; it is not in the same section.
—It is a new section 43A.
—Following section 43.
—Yes, it is to be section 43A. Section 43, entitled ' Principles to be applied by courts', states:

SPEECH.PARA: 43. The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction under this Act or any other Act, and any other court exercising jurisdiction under this Act shall, in the exercise of that jurisdiction, have regard to- (a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

(b) the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society, particularly while it is responsible for the care and education of dependent children;
(c) the need to protect the rights of children and to promote their welfare; and
(d) the means available for assisting parties to a marriage to consider reconciliation or the improvement of their relationship to each other and to the children of the marriage.

The thrust of Senator Missen's amendment is away from reconciliation and towards divorce settlement conciliation. That is precisely the thrust of Senator Missen' s amendment. It is going into that very area in the legislation which was put up in 1975 as a sop to the people who feel very strongly about the institution of marriage. No other part of the legislation, as Senator Missen knows, contains the words 'the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life'. What does the Act then say? Section 48 provides that a marriage can be dissolved after 12 months separation. Then yesterday, the Senate voted that certain marriages could be dissolved by post. Now Senator Missen is attempting to put into that very section--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not doing that.

—Senator Missen is doing that. Given his vote on the previous matter, that is what he is doing in this context. Having regard to what he did before by rejecting the attempts that have been made to provide a pattern of reconciliation, Senator Missen is attempting to change the thrust of this Act to ensure that the facilities of the courts and other areas are focused predominantly on divorce counselling. I believe that is a retrograde step. If it is going to be put in somewhere, do not put it in section 43.
—It is not in section 43.
—It is in section 43. Senator Missen is proposing a new section 43A. It is in the area of section 43. Senator Missen's amendment proposes a new section 43A, as I have repeated time and again.

—Order! I point out, Senator Harradine, to avoid any further confusion, that if this proposed new section is passed it will become section 44 . It is proposed section 43A at the moment only for procedural reasons.
—That is not true, unfortunately. We keep the same numbers.
—It would become a new and appropriate section in the Act. It would not have the same number.
—It is proposed section 43A. It would come immediately after section 43, which I have just read out. Am I right or wrong? That is the point I am making. It is in the scheme-
—How would you like it put somewhere else in the Act? Would you be happy then?

—It would certainly be better placed elsewhere. I do not want it in at all, to be quite frank. I will deal with that in a moment. The Government could deal with it similarly to the way it is dealt with in New Zealand. It should consider that. I do not suggest that it should deal with it in that fashion but it should consider what is done in New Zealand. I will have a copy of the New Zealand legislation available shortly. Unfortunately, it has not yet come to hand. If we look at what is done in New Zealand we will be able to examine whether it is appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Government's attitude is one of support for Senator Missen's amendment. We would take seriously the points that Senator Harradine is making were this to be the only reference in the legislation to conciliation or reconciliation, as the case may be. But, of course, it is not the only reference. It has to be read in the light of the other provisions as they presently stand. It has to be read in the light, first of all, of paragraph (d) of section 43-a different section, notwithstanding its proximity to the proposed form in which Senator Missen moved his amendment, and a section which stands in its own right as a separate and distinct obligation upon the Family Court. It states that in the exercise of its jurisdiction the Court shall have regard to:

SPEECH.PARA: the means available for assisting parties to a marriage to consider reconciliation or the improvement of their relationship to each other and to the children of the marriage.

Right back in the very early part of the Act, section 14 (1), under the heading 'Part III-Counselling and Reconciliation', which is where one would naturally turn in the first instance to find out what the Act says about the matter, states:

Where proceedings for a dissolution of marriage have been instituted . . . it is the duty of the Judge or magistrate constituting the court and of every legal practitioner representing a party to give consideration, from time to time, to the possibility of a reconciliation of the parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a farce, and you know it.

—We are talking about what the spirit, the intention, the symbolic flavour, of the legislation is. If Senator Harradine's argument had any weight at all it was by reference to criteria of those kinds. The practical implementation of these matters is another question. Senator Harradine was talking about what emerges from the whole flavour of the construction and the content of the Act and its individual clauses. That is the truth of the matter. That is the nature of the point which he was making.

SPEECH.PARA: By reference to those criteria which Senator Harradine was applying, the reality of the matter is that this little conciliation clause of Senator Missen' s is outnumbered two to one by reconciliation clauses elsewhere. It is clear that that is the primary thrust. Senator Missen's proposed new clause is there simply to make it clear that in the context of an irretrievable breakdown situation where the dissolution process is irrevocably under way, where the parties have filed for dissolution, very sensibly, the Court is directed to have regard to the possibilities of conciliation of the disputes coming before the Court rather than inexorably forcing the parties into a adversary fighting relationship and having their matters resolved down to the very last blow by the Court itself. It is a direction to the Court to employ, so far as is possible, dispute resolution mechanisms which do not involve the judges themselves, to go outside the Court to try to get a settlement of these matters where there is irreconcilable, irretrievable breakdown, without relying on the Court to arbitrate, determine, decide, adjudicate, every last matter in dispute between the parties.

That is what the proposed new clause is all about. It stands separately and on its own feet. Senator Harradine knows that perfectly well. It would be tragic if the direction to have regard to reconciliation were to be removed entirely from the Act, leaving a direction of this kind. That would seriously undermine one of the basic objectives which we all share, and that is, to try to keep marriages together so far as is humanly possible. That is not the context in which this proposal was put forward. Senator Harradine knows that perfectly well. He has engaged in a last ditch debating point. As we all know, he is a splendid last minute debater. There is no substance whatsoever to the point that he has made. I urge the Committee to accept Senator Missen's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pose the question: Would it be better if the proposed new clause were inserted in part III?

—No, we have placed in this part of the Bill principles to be applied by the courts. Obviously, this is another principle not presently included but which would be followed. If the Family Law Council thought that it was appropriate, it would be applied. The principles should go together and follow one another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -That is the reason I opposed it. It is not a debating point. As Senator Missen said, this clause deals with the principles which should govern the Family Court. The principles which have been established are very high sounding ones. What are they? They are about the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage; the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group of society; the need to protect the rights of the children and promote their welfare, and the means available for assisting the parties to consider reconciliation or the improvement of their relationship to each other in their marriage. They are high sounding principles.

SPEECH.PARA: The new clause would insert a so-called principle. It is not a principle at all ; it is a matter of practicality. Any solicitor worth his salt ought to be referring people to facilities which are available, and not only those provided by the courts. I notice Senator Missen's amendment refers to facilities provided by courts exercising jurisdiction under this Act for counselling to assist parties to marriages and children of marriages to adjust to the consequences of marital breakdown. It does not apply only to the Court. Why just say directed to the 'court exercising jurisdiction'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Read (b). That covers the whole lot.
—No, it does not. It states 'procedures available for the resolution by conciliation of matters arising in the proceedings'. What about the welfare agencies, both voluntary and State?

—Senator Walters asked me a question and on looking at the structure of the Act, I think she probably has a point. Maybe Senator Harradine also has a point. I wonder whether Senator Missen might care to relocate the new section he has proposed. I suggest that it go after section 16 of the Act in Part III which deals with the procedures to be followed in respect of counselling in the context of both counselling and reconciliation. TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I may suggest, Mr President, that it would suit the convenience of the Senate were there to be a cognate debate of the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill 1983, the Archives Bill 1983 and the Copyright Amendment Bill 1983.
—Is that course agreeable to you, Senator Durack?
