SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to address my remarks to the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill. Senator Martin will speak later in relation to the Archives Bill. In confining myself to the amendment of the Freedom of Information Act, perhaps at the outset I may say that the Opposition believes that the proposals in the Bill make some useful and worthwhile amendments to the Act. The Opposition will support the Bill. The Freedom of Information Act came into operation on 1 December last year, after a very prolonged investigation of the proposal over a period of years before the first Bill was introduced into the Parliament by me in 1978. It was then the subject of very detailed consideration by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which produced a report recommending about 100 amendments to that legislation, and subsequently further debate in the Parliament, which gave effect to a considerable number of that Committee's recommendations but by no means to all of them. In particular, it did not give effect to the proposal of that Committee that there should be no conclusive certificates by Ministers under the Freedom of Information Act, and nor did it give effect to recommendations concerning a much wider role for the Ombudsman under that Act.

SPEECH.PARA: In approaching the subject of freedom of information, the previous Government was concerned about the demand on the resources of the Public Service that would arise as a result of the legislation. It must be borne in mind that very new ground was being cultivated in this area. There was widespread concern as to what the impact would be. That occasioned more caution, perhaps, on the part of the previous Government than now seems to have been necessary. Some of the amendments proposed in this Bill involve matters which were not included in the original legislation simply because of concern about the resources that would be required to cope with them and, in particular, such amendments as deal with access to prior documents.

The present Act does not apply to documents that came into existence before 1 December last year unless they relate to a person's personal affairs. The proposal in the Bill is to change that to apply to prior documents back to 1 December 1977, that is, five years prior to the commencement of the Act. That will apply generally, but of course the other provisions in relation to documents concerning a person's personal affairs are untouched. That has made a considerable extension in the right of access to documents and I think it is justified from the experience that has now been had with the Act since 1 December last year which, of course, is some 12 months.

Another major amendment proposed here is the reduction in the time by which an agency must comply with a request. The present Act provides that it must do so within 60 days. This time is to be reduced to 45 days from 1 December 1984 and to 30 days from 1 December 1986. Another amendment which is useful but which may have been thought to have imposed considerable burdens on an agency is the amendment which alters the present provisions in the Act in relation to the furnishing of annual lists of manuals and publications issued by an agency for inspection or purchase. The amendment now requires that to be furnished quarterly, if possible, but at least annually. Any person who requests to inspect or purchase such a document must be notified of all other publications on similar subjects. I just detail those types of amendments which I believe are very important ones but ones about which there was never really any in principle objection. The concern was that there would be too great a demand on existing resources of departments, bearing in mind the time of financial restraint that we were in when this Act was being debated and the requirement, of course, for an unknown increase in the size of the Public Service in order to cope with the demands.

An interesting thing that has occurred since the Act came into operation is the fact that the demand has proved to be nothing like the forecasts that were made by the Public Service, during the period that the Freedom of Information Act was being considered in the Parliament and by the previous Government. The statistics, which I think were first revealed in an answer by the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) to a question in the Senate in May this year, showed that, certainly for the first four months of the operation of the Act, there was a very much less demand than was ever anticipated. I refer the Senate to an answer given on 25 May by the Attorney-General which showed, as I said, that in December there were 716 applications; in January, 593; in February, 699; and in March, 780. In fact, the concentration of requests was in respect of certain departments such as the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Many other agencies have not had any requests at all.

It may have been thought that that was too early to make any judgments, the operation of the Act having commenced only on 1 December, but statistics provided at the Estimates committee hearings a few weeks ago take the Act's operation up to the end of June. They reveal a very similar pattern. The picture seems to be that applications are running at about 700 a month or a little more, with a projected yearly rate of about 9,500, say 10,000 to round it off. I have no doubt that as time goes on there will be greater awareness of the availability of information under the Act, and that is likely to encourage some more applications. I think it is fair to say that the concerns which were very much uppermost in the minds of the previous Government in bringing this Act into operation and in preparing for it, and which were based on the advice of the Public Service at that time, have not been realised, and that certainly justifies the extension of rights which this Bill contains.

The other matter I should like to mention is the great success of the training programs that were conducted, and still are being conducted, by the Attorney- General's Department so that the Public Service generally could be properly instructed in the workings of the Act, the rights of people under the Act, and its obligations under the Act in complying with requests, and so on. Very complicated new procedures are required of the Public Service under the Act. Very extensive training programs were put in train under the leadership of officers from the Attorney-General's Department, starting as early as the end of 1981, I think. Certainly they were conducted very vigorously all through 1982 and they are continuing, but of course there is nothing like the same requirement because the reports that have come forward indicate that as far as the Public Service is concerned the Act is working smoothly. Indeed, an answer that Senator Gietzelt, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, gave in the Senate a few weeks ago about the experience of his Department is a very good example of how well the Act is working and how the Public Service is approaching and administering it.

These are all very satisfactory results, and I must say it is very pleasing that such important new rights which have been created under the Freedom of Information Act are being given full realisation and that the administration of the Act is working smoothly. So although there were, as I said, very considerable fears in the Public Service about the Act, in the event they do not seem to have been justified. Of course digesting the provisions of the Act has been a major operation, and perhaps the Public Service is to be congratulated as well for having so successfully adjusted to the Act and the new rights created by it.

I want now to turn to some of the new policy considerations which are dealt with in the Bill before us. I shall refer to a statement, which the present Attorney-General made when he was in Opposition, in regard to freedom of information generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are plenty of those.
—Yes. I think it is worth recalling that on 8 April 1981 Senator Evans said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . one of the recurring themes in the whole history of freedom of information around the world is the way in which, for obvious reasons, it tends to be espoused as a concept rather more passionately by oppositions out of office than by governments sitting in office.

Senator Gareth Evans certainly was very conscious of that because during the election campaign one of his throwaway lines with which we and the public are familiar, which probably seemed a good idea at the time, was that anything he did would have to be in the first two weeks of office because he was sure that his colleagues would not agree to them after they had been in office longer than that period.

This legislation has proved his point and his fears because the major criticism of the Freedom of Information Act that Senator Gareth Evans always made-by other senators as well, I must admit, on my own side of the chamber, but led by Senator Gareth Evans, the present Attorney-General when he was the shadow Attorney-General-was in relation to the conclusive certificates of Ministers. Of course, the other very firm statement that he made which was part of the policy promises of the present Government in the election campaign-it was made over and over again prior to that-I think can be summed up by saying that an incoming Labor Government would fully adopt all the significant recommendations of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

As I have said, I think the major recommendation, although there were many important ones, of the Senate Committee's report was that requirement for conclusive certificates to be removed from the Bill which ultimately became law, with the conclusive certificate remaining, albeit with some changes which enabled a review process of a ministerial decision by a document review tribunal , but left the final decision to the Minister. The Bill before us, as we might have expected in the light of what Senator Gareth Evans said and in the light of the views of the Senate Committee which he so strongly adopted, would have removed conclusive certificates. I again quote the words of Senator Gareth Evans in the Senate on 8 April 1981 in relation to the debate on the Bill which became the Freedom of Information Act:

The main areas of the battleground clearly, in terms of the things that are out of the Bill but ought to be in it, are, for a start, those provisions recommended by the Senate Committee which would go to limit the practical effect of conclusive ministerial certificates, not least in the area of internal working documents-a description wide enough to include just about any piece of paper in government departments except that which comes in rolls . . .
In the Senate on 29 May 1981 Senator Gareth Evans said:

So long as ministerial discretion in any form is retained absolutely and conclusively to deny access to these documents without being subject to second guessing or review by anyone else, it is our view . . . that freedom of information legislation is simply not worth having unless we can ensure that documents of this kind come within its ambit, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was nothing equivocal about that.
—There was nothing equivocal at all about that statement.
—What a busy little research assistant you have.

—I did not need any research assistance on these matters. I have heard them spoken of by the Attorney-General so passionately in this chamber over a long period that they are engraved in my mind if not on my heart. The position, of course, is that the Bill before us, although it makes some procedural changes in the way conclusive certificates are dealt with, retains the principle of conclusive certificates of Ministers in broadly the areas provided by the Act, namely, in those very sensitive areas-I think that is the phrase Senator Gareth Evans used in his second reading speech when introducing this Bill-of defence, international relations and security. The availability of those documents to the public is conclusively described in the end by the Minister, and so it should be. That was always the argument of the previous Government, put by me when I had responsibility for the carriage of the Bill through the Parliament over that long period. We stuck to that principle and the Act contains that principle. This Bill acknowledges that principle and does not detract in essence from it. I think that is very important and I thoroughly support that, but I cannot help commenting on the very great reversal of attitude by members of this Government from that they adopted in opposition and in the election campaign and, of course, of the leadership of Senator Gareth Evans in promoting very heavy criticism of the existing legislation over such a long period.

SPEECH.PARA: Now in government Senator Gareth Evans has fallen victim of his own warning, if we like to call it that, which I quoted earlier, that the concept of freedom of information seems to be more passionately espoused in opposition than in government. But, of course, the fact is that the previous Government pioneered this legislation, brought it into the Parliament, put it through the Parliament, put the Public Service in shape to cope with its administration, finally brought into operation on 1 December last year an Act which, by all the evidence we have had, as I referred to earlier, is working smoothly and successfully. Therefore, I do not think it is fair to say that the previous Government was in any way lukewarm about the concept of freedom of information. But this Government not only has certainly proved itself lukewarm, but also has positively rejected the centrepiece really of its own view of freedom of information, namely, that there should never be any conclusive certificates.

This Bill, as I have said, does contain some changes in the way of handling conclusive certificates. It abolishes the special Document Review Tribunal which the existing Act contains and provides for the review of conclusive certificates to be done by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. If the Tribunal makes a determination against the Minister, the Minister must, within 28 days, decide whether or not to revoke the certificate. If he does not revoke the certificate, he must lay before the Parliament written notice of his decision not to do so. Of course, the decision is his and his alone in the end. I think that particular provision about tabling the decision in Parliament is a good one. The present Act provides that the decision of the Minister must be made public, so there is certainly a pressure point on the Minister in the existing legislation. This is perhaps a useful development of that idea.

The abolition of the Document Review Tribunal, although it will not be opposed by the Opposition, is a pity. The documents that are dealt with in these very sensitive areas are, as Senator Gareth Evans and the Government now acknowledge, of a character which demand a special tribunal to review a decision of a Minister. I think it needs to be a tribunal which comprises judges of the highest calibre, who command the highest respect. That was the reason why the previous Government provided for a special tribunal. I do not impugn in any way the high quality of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. But the Tribunal is growing larger and larger, with gradations of deputy presidents, senior members and part time members. So it is not really a tribunal which can be identified as having a special role in this area. No doubt, however, the administration of it by the President of the Tribunal will ensure that judges or deputy presidents of the most suitable standing will deal with documents of such a sensitive character as the ones in question.

As I have said, the Opposition supports this measure because it believes that it makes some worthwhile changes to the Act. In ordinary circumstances I would have believed it may be wiser to wait until the Act has been in operation for a year or two before any changes at all are made. But in light of the evidence that is indicated in the statistics to which I have referred, it seems that it is now appropriate to make the changes earlier than would otherwise have been expected. The most pleasing thing of all is the success of the operation of the Freedom of Information Act. As time goes on it will, of course, have even greater impact in providing the public with greater knowledge. Individuals may want to find out about information held about themselves. Indeed, information of any kind in government creates an important right which will be exercised more and more for the benefit of the community as a whole and for the benefit of public discussion on public affairs. It is all part and parcel of a great increase in individual rights in relation to government and the bureaucracy which was put forward by the previous Government.

As I said the other day in this place, freedom of information must be looked at as part of a general package relating to the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and the judicial review of administrative decisions. The result of this exercise which is now in successful operation has been to revolutionise the rights of the citizen in relation to the conduct of government. As I said, it is very pleasing to know that the freedom of information legislation is working so smoothly and successfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my intention today to take up the time of the Senate in debating at length the history in this country of freedom of information, or even the need for it. I suggest that all that can be said about that has already been said again and again over the last decade-most of it, of course, by the present Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). Of course, this raises a problem, since people such as the present Attorney-General have a tendency not unknown among academics and politicians to be carried away by their own rhetoric, and they are then faced with the problem at some later date of having their words come back to haunt them. This has certainly been the case with Senator Gareth Evans and the present Freedom of Information Amendment Bill by which the Government wishes to amend the Freedom of Information Act which was passed after considerable debate, and not some squabbling, under the previous Liberal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: It may well be, as Senator Durack has pointed out, that, when in government, Ministers have rather an enthusiastic interest in restricting access to some types of documents-an interest they did not appear to have when they were holding shadow portfolios in opposition. Yesterday Senator Messner indicated that the converse of this is true in his impassioned plea for the release by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) of certain working documents that the Government apparently used in preparing its assets and income test policy and legislation. I refer anybody who is interested in pursuing that thought to yesterday's Hansard and also to Senator Grimes's equally impassioned rebuttal of Senator Messner's request. Senator Grimes stated what used to happen under the previous Government whenever Senator Chaney was asked to produce documents of a similar kind. This difference in which Ministers see things, depending on which side of the chamber they are on, no doubt explains the quaint disparity between the present Attorney-General's statement in May of this year when issuing the Australian Labor Party's law and justice policy and the contents of the Bill before us today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes they get rolled in Cabinet, of course.

—That is the other possibility. To refresh the Attorney-General's memory and that of anybody else who is interested I will quote item 7.2 under the heading 'The Citizens and Government: Administrative Law'. The paper was put out by Senator Gareth Evans on 23 February this year in Melbourne. The words ' Rewrite the Freedom of Information Act 1982 to implement fully the principles of open government' are underlined. The Attorney-General went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committe on Constitutional and Legal Affairs made over 100 recommendations regarding the proposed Freedom of Information legislation. The Attorney-General accepted only a few of them; some others were forced on him in the Senate. Labor--
said the Attorney-General a little earlier this year-
will implement fully the outstanding recommendations of the Committee to ensure that freedom of information operates in practice as well as in name.

One wonders, as Senator Durack has already pointed out, what has happened to those major areas of recommendation relating to conclusive certificates. On the other hand, it may be possible that since the last piece of legislation went through in a spirit of conciliation and co-operation the Attorney-General is sitting poised to accept Senator Missen's amendments to this area. I will wait and see. Of course, if it is a matter of being rolled, either in Caucus or in Cabinet, we will not see those amendments go through.

Nevertheless, even with the amendments that are brought forward in this Bill, it does not do anything more than make a start on implementing the outstanding recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs as was promised by the Attorney-General in February of this year. It certainly does not provide open government in this country or full access to all but the most secret documents of government and bureaucratic operations.

I accept that the legislation is an improvement. The Australian Democrats certainly intend supporting it wholeheartedly although with some regret that it does not go as far as we would like or as was promised. The Government's proposed amendments, for instance, will further limit exemptions but even so a substantial amount of information which is necessary for the proper understanding of matters of public interest will still remain outside the scope of the legislation and therefore not subject to right of access. The Library Association of Australia, among other organisations, has made submissions relating to the proposed changes to the freedom of information legislation. I refer to a number of comments it made in that submission. It stated:
We wish to comment on three matters specifically:

The Attorney-General himself has noted there has as yet been no move to abolish or to remove the powers which enable Ministers or permanent Heads of Departments to issue conclusive certificates declaring a document or documents to be exempt. This still leaves with Ministers and Departments substantial discretionary powers to withhold material . . .

While some sections of the Liberal Opposition would certainly continue to support that, as Senator Durack indicated, Senator Missen agrees with us and with past comments of the Attorney-General that this should not continue. The Association went on to make the point that:
The Bill contains no proposal to amend or delete S.36 ss 1 (a) which refers to the deliberative material which is prepared, used or consulted by agencies in the course of their work.
The Association finished up by saying:

We consider that unless the Act is further amended it will remain variable in scope, and inconsistent or haphazard in operation and application. Even with the proposed changes it is still doubtful how much information will be retrieved and identified by persons who have only average persistence and resources.

The Library Association of Australia is not the only organisation concerned about omissions in the proposed Bill. The Public Interest Advocacy Centre in Victoria has also expressed concern, as have many other groups, about deficiencies in the present amending Bill. Like the Australian Democrats, it basically supports the proposed amendments, but does not believe that they go far enough. In particular, we commend the proposals in these areas: Firstly, they progressively shorten the time within which agencies are required to answer requests from the present 60 days to 40 days from 1 December 1984 and then to 30 days from 1 December 1986. Secondly, they extend the right of access to documents which have been in the possession of agencies since 1 December 1977, although I must add at this point that we believe that that period should go back a further 20 years, bringing it in line with the period under the Archives Bill. Thirdly, the Bill includes provisions enabling costs to be awarded to applicants in certain cases. As I have said before, and as others have said before me, some areas still need attention. Some of them are apparently administratively trivial but they are important to the public; for instance, addresses to which requests have to be sent. At the moment these are limited to addresses which are listed in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette or in the Commonwealth Government Directory. There have been some problems, which I will refer to again during the Committee stage of the Bill, with people who are sending requests to agency addresses in the telephone book. Other problems relate to proceedings before the Ombudsman and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which again I will refer to when we get to the Committee stage.

Suffice it to say at this point that we welcome the proposed Bill and the amendments as far as they go. However, we are disappointed that the Government did not see its way clear to meet its election promise or the election promise of its Attorney-General-I understand that they are not necessarily one and the same thing-in regard to freedom of information. We will be supporting Senator Missen's amendments as well as pursuing a number of our own, in the hope that the Government or the Opposition will support them. If our amendments and those of Senator Missen go through, along with some additional amendments that the Government is putting forward to its own Bill, I think there is some chance that genuine, open government will operate in Australia so that the concept of freedom of information becomes a force in this country rather than a farce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating cognately three Bills: The Freedom of Information Amendment Bill 1983, the Archives Bill 1983 and the Copyright Amendment Bill 1983. Earlier in this debate this morning Senator Durack, the shadow Attorney-General, responded on behalf of the Opposition on the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill. It is my responsibility this morning to outline the response of the Opposition on the Archives Bill and the Copyright Amendment Bill. I shall be brief. The original Archives Bill was introduced into the Senate by Senator Durack, when he was Attorney-General, in 1978. That Bill, the original Freedom of Information Bill and the Copyright Amendment Bill, were referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts and the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Those committees held hearings, investigated the Bills and reported to the Senate. In 1981, Senator Durack reintroduced the Archives Bill in an amended form consequent on reports of the two Senate committees to which I have referred . That Bill was unfortunately not debated by the Senate and lapsed with the prorogation of Parliament earlier this year for the general election.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have the Archives Bill mark 3, which is the Archives Bill 1983, introduced into the Senate earlier this year by the present Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans). The Archives Bill is substantially the same as that introduced in 1981 by the previous Government, with some amendments. It provides for the proper disposition of records of Commonwealth agencies in an efficient and economical manner and in a manner that will facilitate their use. It should be borne in mind that in debate on the Archives Bill we are essentially talking about records that are more than 30 years old; the Freedom of Information Act and the amendments to that Bill refer to records that are basically less than 30 years old. So the Archives Bill complements the Freedom of Information Act with respect to the keeping of records and reasonable access to Commonwealth records.

The Archives Bill also replaces what has been operating on a non-statutory basis for quite a number of years. We have, of course, had an Australian Archives, but this was not provided for under an Act. This Bill brings together all those things that are necessary for properly constituted archives and gives the Australian Archives a statutory basis. It also gives the Australia Archivist , Dr Neale, a statutory basis. I am sure Dr Neale will be relieved that there is a possibility that he will be legal under an Act of Parliament before his retirement, having acted in his present position for some time. There are some changes between the Archives Bill 1983 and the Archives Bill 1981 in relation to extension of coverage of records, access to records, disposal practices, charging for services and review of decisions. The Opposition supports all those changes.

I would like to refer just briefly to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and a couple of issues that it raised. I shall raise these again briefly in Committee, but I think it is appropriate that I mention them now. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee report on the Archives Bill raised four matters. The Government has responded to two of those matters with proposed amendments to the Archives Bill that have been circulated by the Attorney-General. However, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report does refer to the fact that in one of the important areas of change between the Archives Bill 1981 and the Archives Bill 1983, important details will be given effect to by regulation.

One of the extensions of the Bill is an extension to cover the records of parliament and of the administrative records of courts. The Archives Bill provides that the details of that access and what will be made available are to be negotiated with the officers of the Parliament, the Speaker and the President , and with the relevant people in relation to court records. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee raised the point that this rather important change in access to records will be done by regulation.

I accept and appreciate that this is a new area and it will be necessary for some quite extensive consultation and discussions, I would think, on just which records will be made available and how. However, I hope that when this process of consultation is completed we may see an amendment to what will be by then, I assume, the Archives Act, so that that important innovation will not be just left in regulations, but will come under the scope of the Act.

The other point which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee quite properly made is a small one but it is, nevertheless, quite a proper point to make. There is provision that there could be a reduction of time available to the Australian Archives to respond to requests for information. The Bill presently provides that the Archives will have to notify an applicant of its decision within a maximum of 90 days. As the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has said, it is unlikely that anyone would find his or her civil liberties infringed if it were decided to reduce the period for response to a request from a member of the public. However, it is an important factor in the Bill. I am informed that it is hoped that it will be possible to reduce that time, after some experience of working with the Bill, to bring it closer to the Freedom of Information Act provisions. Time will tell what is possible there.

I just reiterate what I said in relation to my previous point regarding regulations. Whilst I am sure that a reduction of time for response by the Archives would be welcomed, the Parliament would also welcome such a statutory reduction if it were a reduction and not done just under regulation. Regulation may be satisfactory initially, particularly if there were an experimental phase with the new period.

I turn my attention briefly to the Copyright Amendment Bill and amendments made to the Copyright Act consequential upon provisions of the new Archives Bill. The provision, which is simple enough, provides for broadcasting and television organisations to deposit ephemeral records with the Archives. We are told that ephemeral records include videotape, cinematographic film and sound records. The amendments are supported by the Opposition.

I take this opportunity to make a couple of quick comments on the provision that these ephemeral records may go to the Archives, subject of course to the consent of the Director-General of the Australian Archives, instead of to the National Library of Australia. The subject of film archives and their handling by the National Library has been a matter of quite some contention in recent and not so recent times. It is a matter that has been pursued at length in this chamber and specifically in Senate Estimates committees by Senator David Hamer and me. What is claimed to be a basically unsatisfactory handling of that particular form of ephemeral record has been detailed in this place. More recently, some criticism has been made outside the Parliament of the sound archives situation in Australia. The debate has recently been joined by the National Library and also the Government.

I just hope that in the debate on the fate of the film archives we might have a little less confusion and alarmism than we have had in recent times. I welcome the fact that the National Library is responding to the subject of how it is handling film archives. However, I am not entirely satisfied with the answer the National Library has given. I understand that funds have been a problem in relation to the treatment of film archives. However, I am not persuaded that the National Library has given very much priority to the film archives in the past and to the subject of disposition of its funds. Whatever the outcome of the debate on whether film archives ought to remain with the National Library- whether they ought to go to some special statutory body of their own, which I must say I do not think is entirely necessary, or whether they might remain with the Library but be relocated in a city other than Canberra-I hope that it is a reasoned debate that pays attention to all the needs of the film archives.

I certainly pay tribute to the National Library for its foresight in instituting both film archives and sound archives in the past. They are very important records for a nation to have. Demands for access to film archives have been sharpened in recent years with the growth-indeed the virtual explosion-of the film industry in Australia. They are archives of very particular significance and importance to the film industry, but not only the film industry . Other people also need access to them. When the dust has settled and the debate has resolved the issue one way or the other I hope that the solution will not be one of anyone's empire building being protected or of anyone's particular special interest being looked after at the expense of others. I hope that these very important archives can be sensibly handled.

I pay tribute to the dedication that Dr Neale has brought to the general subject of archives in Australia. At Estimates committee hearings he has given us many a lecture on the needs of the Australian Archives. There is no excuse for anyone who has attended the hearings of the Estimates committee which handles the estimates for the Australian Archives not to have a very detailed knowledge of its operations. As I said, I pay tribute to the work Dr Neale has done for the Archives. I am sure that the dedication he has brought to the subject of the protection of Commonwealth records is a dedication he will lend also to the protection of the ephemeral records which will be judged to be properly part of the national Archives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill, the Archives Bill and the Copyright Amendment Bill. I am afraid that perhaps I will not purr quite as much as the last two speakers, who made complimentary remarks about the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill, a Bill which I find still very deficient. I think Senator Durack has reason to be pleased with the fact that, after the event, there is some justification for the views he expressed. It seems that the Government, at least at present, has come to a similar conclusion on conclusive certificates, although it may have tried to dress them up in a slightly different disguise.

SPEECH.PARA: But I am afraid that this Bill is just an improvement on the existing law. It is part of a battle in a long fight. I am sure that fight will go on. I am confident that in the end many more of the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs will be adopted.

I find it strange not only that there are so few Australian Labor Party members of the Senate present today but also that, apparently, none of them, except the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), will be speaking on this Bill because there was a great deal of interest in this chamber when the previous Bill went through in 1980-81. It was very highly criticised by members of the Labor Party when in Opposition. It is surprising that they are not here today to praise the amendments coming forward which, I readily concede, are improvements on the existing law.

I support the three Bills but I intend to devote all my time in this speech to the major Bill, the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill. Let me briefly recapitulate the situation. When the original Bill was before the Senate it was subjected to one of the most thorough and detailed examinations by a Senate committee ever under my chairmanship. Senator Gareth Evans was Deputy Chairman of that Committee and he did an enormous amount of work in connection with our investigation and recommendations. Only a limited number of those recommendations were adopted by the previous Government. Indeed, many negotiations went on to try to increase the extent to which the Committee's recommendations would be met. I remind the Senate that at that time I produced a document which I headed 'Seven Deadly Sins of Omission'. That document is a useful guide today to how far we have gone in improving freedom of information. The seven deadly sins which I said were not adequately dealt with in the original Bill and which were only partially cured related, firstly, to conclusive ministerial certificates. That remains a matter which, although disguised by a new dress, is still very much an abomination in this legislation. The second matter concerned the provisions with regard to existing government records and the extent to which they were to be disclosed. The government of the day was of the opinion that there would be extensive usage of the Act. Some of the witnesses before the Senate Committee were quite hysterical; they expected enormous usage of the Act. That expectation has been proved to be false. That leads me to amendments which the Government is proposing in this area covering documents up to five years old and which I think could go further.

The third point I made related to the grounds of exemption of documents. Although we do not have much in the way of amendments from the Government, I think that in this area one must look at the Act in running. I have no doubt that today certain misuses are taking place with regard to the rather loosely worded exemptions. I think we will find that, when the Attorney-General's Department, the Commonwealth Ombudsman and other people report to the Parliament and when the committees of this Parliament look into the way in which the Act has operated over the first year or so, we will see that something certainly should be done to tighten up exemptions. But I do not think this is quite the t- -e for that to happen.

The fourth of my deadly sins was in regard to the lack of provision for personal records. That was substantially improved by the previous Government and I think there is now a sensible provision in that area. The fifth deadly sin was the wide exemption for government agencies. We had undertakings that these were to be looked at over the years so that we could reduce the number of exemptions and partial exemptions. I think this is a matter of ongoing concern for the Parliament. The sixth was the Ombudsman's conciliatory counselling and monitoring roles in relation to freedom of information. A substantial number of amendments were proposed-I am again proposing them today-and were not taken up in the previous Act. The last was the secrecy provisions in existing legislation , which are also a part of unfinished business.

So one should not go overboard in saying that the amendments before us today have taken us very far down the road to achieving some of the objectives which the Senate Committee was trying to achieve. There were negotiations with the Government at that time. A number of my colleagues in the then Government tried to come up with the best Bill that could possibly go through the Senate while that Government had a majority. We were, of course, very heavily abused by members of the then Opposition in this chamber and in the House of Representatives for our inability to stand up long enough to vote and for our generally weak-kneed attitude to questions of freedom of information. Perhaps the chickens are coming home to roost today. We must remind ourselves-I do not want to be tedious about this-that the previous Opposition had given very considerable undertakings to the Parliament; for example, Mr Lionel Bowen, MP, who was very strong on abusing me during the passage of the Bill, in speaking about what a Labor government would do, said:
The amendments which have been moved in the Senate will be moved again in this House.

Honourable senators will remember that there were some 80 amendments altogether on the list which a number of honourable senators on both sides of the chamber had originally drafted. Mr Lionel Bowen continued:

They are not being moved for the sake of rhetoric or point scoring. We believe that all governments should pass legislation such as we have proposed. If it cannot be done by this Government it will be done by a Labor Government. The Government rushed the legislation through the Senate during the last session. It said it had gone so far and would go no further. That is still not far enough.
Then he referred to my statement that the Bill was weak but that we hoped to improve it in 10 years time. I am hopeful that we will do it more quickly than that.
In the course of the election campaign a very clear undertaking was given in the law and justice policy of the Australian Labor Party. It stated:

Labor will implement fully the outstanding recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs to ensure that freedom of information operates in practice as well as in name.

That was not a partial promise or part of the more important recommendations; it was an undertaking which no doubt a number of people in the community found acceptable. My criticism is not of the Attorney-General, who I think has fought strongly and consistently over the years in support of the Committee's recommendations. But, as has been pointed out by Senator Durack, the Attorney- General was somewhat aware of the difficulty that would arise if he could not proceed quickly. Senator Durack was a little kind to him because he did not quote the whole article in the Canberra Times of 5 June this year which stated that Senator Gareth Evans wryly commented during the election compaign that any government which intended to increase access to Government information had to do it in its first fortnight before it had any secrets to hide, otherwise it would never do it at all. In saying that, however, he was confidently asserting that he could do it. Unfortunately, that confidence has not proved to be justified. Unfortunately, the Sir Humphreys around the Government have succeeded in greatly limiting this legislation, particularly in the area of conclusive certificates and in the area of the Ombudsman's powers-matters which I will be raising today. The achievements of this new Bill which fairly must be put into perspective are that it does include the five-year-old documents and it will now be a useful expansion of the existing records of the Government. I think that is a valuable improvement.

There are changes in the Bill in regard to Commonwealth-State documents, and those changes accord with the recommendations of the Senate Committee. I believe that they will be useful. Likewise, we had the somewhat tortuous progress of the public interest clauses. In the course of debate in this chamber I sought to have included a number of exemptions so that it would also have to be established that it was in the public interest that information be withheld. Those provisions went into the subsequent Victorian legislation adopted by the Thompson Government and are now contained in the present legislation which the Cain Government has adopted in Victoria. Now they are contained in the Bill before us and I welcome them very much.

There are useful provisions in regard to costs in this amending Bill which I think will be helpful to people. The practicalities of the operation of freedom of information must be constantly kept in mind, for example, whether or not it will be used, whether the Bill is just a good looking document or one that has practical operation for people who have very little money. That, of course, has a relevance to the amendments I will be moving in respect of the use of the Ombudsman in this legislation. There are changes concerning the factual documents attached to Cabinet papers which will now be disclosed. So it will not be possible to hide documents by attaching them to files that happen to go before Cabinet. Improvements are foreshadowed in the Bill with respect to response times to applications. These are quite useful.

Other provisions in the Bill that have not been mentioned relate to national security provisions, documents which have been obtained from foreign governments and documents which come from the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and which are in the hands of other departments. I made a close study of the progress of freedom of information in the United States early this year and I talked to many people who are concerned. They are not concerned that the American Congress is likely greatly to ruin or weaken the Act but they are concerned about the action of the Administration in America, the presidential directives and the threats against public servants if they do not use their efforts against disclosure. There are considerable dangers to the American Act and the way in which it might operate. Whilst I think that the provisions in regard to national security are satisfactory, I warn the Government against going too much further in this direction if, as a result of the inquiries that are taking place at the moment, suggestions are made that the national security restrictions on freedom of information should be increased. There are also improvements in the administration of the Act, to which Senator Durack made reference, and I think they are to be welcomed.

I come back to what I think are the two major disappointments. I believe that they are major disappointments despite the efforts of the Attorney-General. I refer to the failure to deal with the subject of conclusive certificates except in a merely casual and superficial way. When one looks at the debate on this subject in this chamber back in 1981 one finds the importance which the then Opposition, in the words of Senator Gareth Evans, placed on conclusive certificates. On 29 May 1981 the Committee had reached the stage where it was dealing with conclusive ministerial certificates, which is clearly one of the most central issues in this debate. Senator Gareth Evans suggested that certain clauses be debated together. In a number of areas he made it clear that this was a central issue, as it was, so far as getting rid of a power which a Minister has to make a declaration, and that is what a conclusive certificate is-being able to say that it was against the public interest for the document to be examined or for any applicant to have possession of it. There is no power to go beyond that. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which is a very respectable body, is now to have the power of recommendation, but that power is one which the Minister can immediately ignore and say: 'On my reading of it, it is not right'. The position, I think, is fairly sad.

I wish to quote from an interesting submission which was made to the Attorney- General on 4 August 1983 by Susan Acutt, the Executive Director of the Library Association of Australia, which applauded the review of the legislation. In relation to this specific matter, the submission stated:

The Attorney-General himself has noted there has as yet been no move to abolish or to remove the powers which enable Ministers or permanent Heads of Departments to issue conclusive certificates declaring a document or documents to be exempt. This still leaves with Ministers and Departments substantial discretionary powers to withhold material, even given the exercise of a public interest criterion, a principle which is always difficult to apply. Abolishing of the Special Documents Review Tribunal and the extension of the power of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to allow for appeals concerning certificates are not sufficient, especially since the onus of substantiating an appeal will fall on those claiming that material should not be exempt.

The Association made a major criticism of that lack in the legislation. It was one of the fundamental recommendations of the Senate Committee which is not being implemented. It has been suggested by Senator Tate in debates which have taken place in this chamber-I regret that he is not here today-that the Executive must not be the final arbiter in these matters. That is so. At present the Executive is the final arbiter on whether some embarrassing document, which may not suit it at all to disclose, is one that can be stopped from coming to public knowledge. I foreshadow that today I will move amendments in respect of conclusive certificates. I do not have any illusions; I do not expect the amendments to succeed. In the previous Parliament the then Opposition was not in favour, as was the then Government, of the conclusive certificate idea. The Government and Opposition have certainly not been convinced by me, but I trust I will have what support I can. The campaign will go on to remove this blot from the Act.

I foreshadow that I will move amendments regarding a second area. I am much more encouraged to think that I will have more success in that area. The amendments concern the use of the Ombudsman under the Act. We know that the Ombudsman, in his present position, can play some useful role. What is proposed is a much wider role than he is given under the present Act. In regard to the role of the Ombudsman, Senator Gareth Evans made the same sorts of remarks when the matter was considered by us on 12 June 1981:
In regard to the Ombudsman, these amendments are an absolutely central part of the Opposition's approach to this legislation . . .
Debate interrupted.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EARLY RELEASE OF PRISONERS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Has he seen the reported comments of Professor Tony Vinson, the former head of the Corrective Services Commission of New South Wales about allegations of corruption in that State's prison system? In particular, I ask whether he has noted Professor Vinson's claim that the police told him that a judicial inquiry was needed and the professor's conclusion that the report from the current police investigation 'won't be worth the paper it apparently has yet to be written on because the police directly concerned told me that it could not be productive of the truth'? Does the Attorney-General agree that these views from a man who was once in charge of the New South Wales prison system indicate the need for an independent and public inquiry into allegations about the former early release system?

—I have not seen in any detail Professor Vinson's comment referred to by Senator Chaney but I have assumed the accuracy of Senator Chaney' s account of the general substance of it. I simply say to him that the quality of any New South Wales police investigation of the matters to which he refers is not something on which I am qualified to pass a judgment or would care to make a judgment or am equipped by my portfolio responsibilities to make a judgment.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Resources and Energy been drawn to reported comments of the Queensland Liberal Party leader on State Government charges on the mining industry that 'charges are being levied without taking into account the industry's need for competitiveness' and that ' governments should share in the benefits of the good times and, as with companies and their employees, cut its cloth in bad times'? Can the Minister say whether these comments by the Queensland Liberal Party leader are consistent with the Commonwealth Government's approach to mineral taxation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice a report in yesterday's Australian Financial Review which I think is identical to both the general tone which Senator Childs has reported to the Senate and to the specific quotation he has given from the Queensland Liberal Party leader. I also note that the Queensland Liberal Party leader is reported to have said that for the benefit of the whole community the profit returns from the existing rail freight system should be released. I make two observations in reply to Senator Childs. Firstly, it shows or suggests a significant shift on the part of the Queensland Liberal Party towards the policy which is being advocated by the Australian Labor Party in Queensland and the Opposition Leader, Mr Wright. Second, of course, it is fully compatible with the view on resource industry taxation which the Australian Labor Party has held for six years and which is currently being pursued by this Government, directly with respect to crude oil and, hopefully, at some later stage, in respect of at least export quality coal. Given, however, that the Liberal Party in Queensland held the position of Treasurer in the Queensland Government for some 25 years, some people might suspect that the present Liberal Party leader is embarking upon an election stunt. But, if we give him the benefit of the doubt and assume that this is a genuine conversion and a genuine enlightenment on the part of the Queensland Liberal Party towards a more efficient and rational method of taxation of the resources industry, arising from a realisation of the considerable damage that the present system of levy-based or production-based taxation is inflicting on the Queensland mining industry, I certainly welcome it .

ANSWER.PARA: The levy system based on production and taxes-both covert like the railway charges to which Mr White is reported to have referred, and overt in the form of royalties even if they are not subject to ad hoc or even capricious change, as they frequently have been in Queensland-has done and is doing considerable damage to the mining industry. If this is a genuine conversion on behalf of the Queensland Liberal Party, I however do not hold out much hope that should there be a coalition government in Queensland after the election on 22 October the enlightenment of the Queensland Liberal Party would be reflected in the policies of that government. I do hope that the Federal Liberal Party as well as the Liberal Party in Queensland-giving Mr White the benefit of the doubt-will come to see the virtues of the type of alternative taxation system for resources industries which this Government, as I said earlier, is pursuing directly with respect to crude oil and hopefully, through the States, with respect to export quality coal.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware of an interview on the AM program by Mr Fred Silvester, a former head of the Federal Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, concerning the general lack of resolution by governments in pursuing organised crime? Does the Attorney-General agree that the Federal Government has, to use Mr Silvester's words, been playing cat and mouse in its approach to organised crime? Has this view not been given added impetus by the Caucus decision to defer action on the national crimes authority which Senator Evans had been proposing?

—I did not have the benefit of hearing Fred Silvester's views of the world on AM this morning or any other morning, but I am prepared again to take Senator Durack's word for it that he did say something along the lines indicated. The situation is that there has been no lack of resolution by this Government in dealing with the question of organised crime, as is indicated not least by our continuation in existence of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, which has, as everyone is well aware, a rather splendid record-and splendidly embarrassing record, so far as the Opposition is concerned-in dealing with just that phenomenon.
—How much hard evidence?

—That is a matter that will become apparent in the courts as successive prosecutions wend their way to fruition. There is a further report recently to hand from the Costigan Commission the substance of which will not be made public simply because charges have been laid. We do have the special prosecutors Redlich and Gyles in the process of bringing many other matters before the courts. But it is a difficult and tricky process and I readily acknowledge the desirability and necessity for outfits of this kind to concentrate on gathering admissible evidence. But the proof of the pudding will be in the final resolution of those matters now coming before the courts. Equally, the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking had its terms readily extended, at the request of His Honour Mr Justice Stewart, to deal with matters that he was concerned with and finish that particular investigation. Of course, he has since had new terms of reference given to him jointly by the Commonwealth Government and the New South Wales Government to deal with the matter of Nugan Hand, which does raise a very large number of detailed and very sensitive questions about organised criminal activity in this country. It is wholly desirable, in my view, and that of the Cabinet, that we proceed to get these sorts of institutions and mechanisms on foot in some more permanent, ongoing, co-ordinated and systematic fashion. We have not leapt into the immediate implementation of the previous Government's National Crimes Commission because there were many defects in the form of that legislation as it was finally enacted by this Parliament and because we wanted to respond systematically and sensitively to the very many concerns that were being expressed from within the legal profession and civil liberties organisations in particular about some of the more potentially alarming aspects of a permanent crime investigation body of that kind. I believe, as I have indicated, that we are very close to a resolution of this matter. It is only a matter of time, certainly this year, before something is on foot which will satisfy everyone in this respect, to the extent that it is possible to do so, and certainly will satisfy the States, which is a darn sight more than the previous Government was ever able to achieve in this area.

—Before I was interrupted again, I was drawing to the Senate's attention, in response to Senator Maguire's question, the fact that a year ago in Queensland there were 21 applications for every job that was available. That, of course, was not good. But in just that year, that figure has increased to 83- there are now 83 applications for every job available. In South Australia a year ago there were 50 applications for every job available, and that figure has increased marginally to 58. That demonstrates yet again the severity of the economic downturn, even the collapse, of the Queensland economy. The hoary old excuse used by the Government of Queensland for a high rate of unemployment over quite a long period has been that population has drifted up from the south. That has been the traditional excuse for a chronically high rate of unemployment in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: In conclusion, I note that that hoary old traditional excuse provides no explanation for the enormous increase in the number of unemployed people in Queensland in the last year and the equally enormous relative decrease in the number of jobs available. That can be attributed only to the very serious and continuing deterioration of the Queensland economy, which is retarding the national economic recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for August 1983 and to the table in those statistics which refers to the capital city employment rates in Brisbane and in Adelaide. Is the Minister aware of the fact that the unemployment rate in the city of Brisbane in August 1983 was 9.3 per cent and that the unemployment rate in the city of Adelaide, to which he has been referring, was 11.5 per cent-in other words, unemployment in Adelaide was nearly 2 per cent higher than in Brisbane? Also, is the Minister aware that the participation rate in Brisbane is at least half a per cent higher than the participation rate in Adelaide? Does not the Minister agree that those figures show that he has been selectively quoting figures and distorting the situation for narrow political purposes to do with the Queensland election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some figures here which I think-I cannot be certain, because they are handwritten-have come from the same table as the table to which Senator Chaney referred. At least one of them is identical. I think Senator Chaney said that in August 1982--

—August 1983. I will give the figures. I am not trying to hide anything. In the metropolitan area of South Australia, which I think is the city of Adelaide-it may include one or two provincial towns but I think it is the city of Adelaide-a year ago the unemployment rate was 9 per cent. This has now risen to 11 1/2 per cent. That is an increase of just over 25 per cent. In Brisbane, however, a year ago the unemployment rate, it is true, was relatively low, at 5.8 per cent, somewhat below the national average. That figure has increased to 9.3 per cent, which is an increase of almost 60 per cent in the unemployment rate in the city of Brisbane in the last 12 months. What those figures, on which Senator Chaney has specifically invited me to comment, reveal, is that although in association with the general economic decline of the last 12 months, induced by the mismanagement of the previous Government and the discredited former Treasurer in particular, there has been some deterioration of the unemployment situation in the city of Adelaide, there has been an enormous deterioration of the unemployment situation in the city of Brisbane. Although nationally the decline can be attributed to a number of factors, the major one of which I have already mentioned, that is, the mismanagement of the discredited former Treasurer, those sorts of regional variations, I suggest, can be attributed substantially to the mismanagement or otherwise of State governments. What those factors show is that the Queensland economy has been managed very badly over the previous 12 months.

ANSWER.PARA: As a final comment, it is correct that, until a year ago, the rate of unemployment in the city of Brisbane, and I think in the State of Queensland generally, was marginally below the national average. There was at that time quite substantial investment in resource projects and that provided a temporary boost, relative to the rest of the country, to the Queensland economy. That has now disappeared and the true nature of the Queensland economy and of the skill or otherwise of the Bjelke-Petersen Government at managing that economy are now being reflected. The State of Queensland is in a desperate and rapidly deteriorating economic position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister : Stripped of all of the rhetoric, is it not a fact that those figures show that unemployment is more than 20 per cent higher in the Labor-run city of Adelaide than it is in the National Party-run city of Brisbane?

—It is correct that, in round figures, the rate of unemployment in the city of Adelaide is 20 per cent higher than the prevailing rate of unemployment in Brisbane. It is also a fact that a year ago, when a Liberal government was in power in South Australia, the rate of unemployment in the city of Adelaide was more than 50 per cent higher than it was in the city of Brisbane . So the differential-since Senator Chaney seems to think that that is important -between the cities of Adelaide and Brisbane, which a year ago was more than 50 per cent under a Liberal government, after 12 months of Labor government in South Australia, has been brought down to 20 per cent.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of a recent call by the Australian Press Council for the repeal of provisions in the Royal Commissions Act giving commissions the power to punish for contempt? In the light of the considerable controversy over this issue in recent times, will the Government review the Act in accordance with the call from the Australian Press Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the reports of the Press Council statement on this matter. I think they should be looked at in a context which is not always fully appreciated, and that is that the powers of royal commissions to punish for contempt are more limited than those of the courts to the extent that the commission has itself power to punish for contempt, but only for wilful contempt in the face of the commission, and if the commissioner is a judge other kinds of cases of contempt can only be proceeded with in the ordinary courts by way of separate prosecutions. Having said that, it is still the case that there are wide-ranging powers of contempt in relation to royal commissions, that those have come under public attention and scrutiny in recent times and that there may well be a case for the review of those powers. I have always had something of a sympathy for the view that the law of contempt as it applies to commissions of inquiry ought to be rather narrower than it is and confined to contempts in the face of the court or involving wilful disruption. Indeed it may be recalled that I moved an amendment to that effect to the previous Government's National Crimes Commission Bill, in which a much more broad- ranging contempt power was proposed to be inserted.

ANSWER.PARA: At this stage I can say no more than this: The whole matter of contempt not only of courts but also of tribunals and royal commissions has already been referred by me, on 7 April this year, to the Law Reform Commission for report. It will be recalled that that was in the aftermath of, among other things, the Gallagher case in the High Court, which raised again quite fundamental questions about the law of contempt as it applied in the courts. But equally the terms of reference of that reference to the Law Reform Commission were deliberately cast so as to be broad enough to include references to the law of contempt before tribunals generally. I will certainly ensure that the views of the Press Council are made known to the Law Reform Commission and I anticipate, with some keen interest, the report coming from the Commission, although given present resource difficulties and competing priorities it may be some time before that report is available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is directed to the Attorney-General. I ask the Attorney whether he has noted an article in the latest Newsweek, the issue of 10 October, saying:

QUESTION.PARA: For better or worse, the Central Intelligence Agency is back in the business of covert action, with a global scope and intensity of resources unmatched since its hey-day 20 years ago.

CIA support services are said in that article to include several banks in the United States of America and abroad. In view of that statement and repeated and continuing allegations of CIA involvement with the Nugan Hand Bank to carry out illegal and damaging acts to Australia and Australians, can the Attorney assure the Senate that the law will be strictly and universally applied to all foreign nationals, investigations held if breaches of Australian law are suspected, charges pressed and penalties imposed if the breaches are proved? While conceding the need and usefulness of legal co-operation between the CIA and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, I ask the Minister: Does machinery exist so that the Government will always know what that co-operation involves? Finally, can the Attorney assure us that the alleged security interests of any foreign country cannot be a justification or excuse for crimes committed in this country and that the staff of ASIO are or will be under instructions to recognise that policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article in Newsweek referred to by the honourable senator. As to the general part of his question, which he addressed in his conclusion, I can say this: It is very much part of the Government's policy to ensure that in accordance with international law no foreign intelligence organisations are allowed to conduct covert activities on Australian soil. So far as the earlier part of the question is concerned, relating specifically to the Nugan Hand issue and questions that have arisen from time to time in relation to that, the new letters patent that were issued to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking in March this year require the Royal Commission to investigate, among other matters, whether persons associated with the Nugan Hand group have carried out illegal activities in Australia. Should that or any other investigation reveal breaches of Commonwealth laws by anyone, I repeat anyone, the question of prosecution will be considered in the normal way without fear or favour, whoever, I repeat whoever, the possible offenders may be.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Attorney-General whether the staff of ASIO are or will be under instructions to recognise that policy.
—The staff of ASIO are entirely familiar with that policy. Despite some rumours from some quarters to the contrary, the staff of ASIO are in the habit of observing both government policy and the law.

—Can the Acting Minister for Health advise whether there has been an agreement with the Queensland Government to fund a national disease control program on a dollar for dollar basis for the control of mosquito borne diseases such as dengue fever and Australian encephalitis? As such agreements with Victoria, New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia have already been announced, can the Minister advise when the Queensland agreement will be announced? —Senator Reynolds has long taken an interest in the national disease control program.
—Since you gave her the question.

—No, I did not give her the question. The honourable senator has it wrong again. If I had given her the question I would have the answer here on my desk.
