The details of and the reasons for that delay are, as I recall it, again related to the problem of getting the Queensland Government to co-operate with any Commonwealth initiative. I will get the exact details of the program for Senator Reynolds later.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Finance whether an arrangement by shareholders to liquidate a company to avoid taxation on the distribution of capital profits, such as that undertaken by Coomel Pty Ltd, constitutes an asset stripping operation similar to that envisaged by the legal parts of the bottom of the harbour schemes which the Government now seeks to tax ?
—I am not familiar with the details of the company to which Senator Lewis's question referred. I will pass that question on to the Minister for Finance for an answer.
—You are familiar with Horgan's affairs.

—I do, however, know that it bears absolutely no similarity to the devices employed by the former chairman of the Liberal Party finance committee in Western Australia, Mr Denis Horgan, since Senator Withers reminded me of it, by which-this was published on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald approximately one year ago-the Metro group of companies evaded $7m in taxation and for which, according to recent Press reports, a liability of more than $4m has already been assessed and sent out by the Commissioner of Taxation or the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation. There is absolutely no connection with the devices employed by Mr Horgan, and, I might add, by at least five other of the fifteen members of the Western Australian Liberal Party finance committee at that time. They used bottom of the harbour operators to appoint phony directors to sink these companies to the bottom of the harbour. As a result of legislation introduced by the last Liberal Government and supported by the then Opposition and some others, Mr Horgan's companies are currently receiving assessments for at least $4m of evaded tax.
—How do you know that?
—It has been in the Press. Are you another, like Senator Withers, who does not read the newspapers?
—Order! The Minister will address his remarks through the Chair.

—I do not know whether Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle wishes to plead ignorance of these matters because she does not read the newspapers, but it has been commonly reported and I stipulated that earlier in answering the question. In conclusion, I leave this as an open question: Even if the fact that just about half the Western Australian Liberal Party's finance committee was up to its ears in bottom of the harbour tax operations--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Without taking sides, I think we are getting on to dangerous ground, upon which you should look carefully. Names are being mentioned by the Minister of people who are not in a position to defend themselves in this chamber. Also the name of a Minister is being shouted out by certain honourable senators on your left, that Minister not being a member of this chamber. I think that on a Friday morning we can allow tempers to come to the surface, but if you, Mr President, allow to continue this sort of name calling of people who are not in a position to defend themselves, with great respect, I suggest we could be establishing a fairly dangerous and undesirable precedent.

—Mr President, may I speak to the point of order? A quite simple question was put to the Minister. It related to comparing the nature of a sale or a distribution of capital profits through a liquidation with a dry Slutzkin, to use the common expression. I would simply say that not only have various names been thrown in, which has happened dozens of times in this chamber over the last year or so, but also the Minister is proceeding to debate the question again with very great enthusiasm without dealing with the substance of the question at all. So, I support the point of order raised by Senator Chipp but add that I think quite clearly there is a breach of the Standing Orders in that the question is not being addressed but is being debated.

—I do not think there is a point of order at this stage. The Minister is still answering the question, but I suggest that he avoid a tendency to debate the matter, in accordance with standing order 100. There is another point and that is that some of these matters-I am not sure of this-may be before a court. I mention that matter before the Minister continues.

—I was just about to conclude. Even if the fact that almost half the Liberal Party's Western Australian finance committee at that stage had not been exposed as being involved in trading with bottom of the harbour dealers or in bottom of the harbour operations was not related to the failure of the then Government to prosecute in time, I certainly suggest that the failure of the Fraser Government to take legislative action against those operators until it could see itself staring down the barrel of a certain electoral defeat if it continued failing to take such action is related to the fact that so many senior people in the Liberal Party were directly associated with bottom of the harbour operations.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the last part of Senator Walsh's answer, I ask him: Is his Government considering taking legislative action against people who involve themselves in the distribution of capital profits through liquidation of a company?

—A Bill is currently before the Senate to do precisely that and to recover the personal taxation which was avoided or evaded through that sort of action. Senator Lewis will have the opportunity to vote for that Bill, I expect next week, if he believes such action should be taken, as will every other honourable senator on the other side of the chamber.

—Does the Minister representing the Treasurer recall that when Mr Jeff Kennett was elected Leader of the Opposition in Victoria he gave several interviews in which he indicated that he no longer participated in his previous private business? Does he also recall that the only connection between Mr Kennett and that company is that he is provided with a free Mercedes Benz every year? Will the Minister investigate whether the company allows as a tax deduction the provision of that car to an individual who contributes nothing to the firm?

—I am not able to confirm or deny the facts regarding Mr Kennett's declaration that he had absolutely no association with, or made no contribution to, his previous business or the disclosure that he was provided by that company with a Mercedes Benz car without charge. Knowing Senator Ray's meticulous attention to detail on such matters, I have little doubt that that is correct.
—And to other matters as well.

—To that and other matters. I note Senator Ray's meticulous attention to detail and accuracy in general. As to the application of the Taxation Act to the set of circumstances which he outlined, I will not attempt to cite the relevant section of the Act, but there is a section in the Income Tax Assessment Act which refers to income in kind being derived from any source. In the general application of that section the free provision of a car by a firm to a person who had no employee relationship with that firm would either have to be assessed as income in the hands of the person receiving the free car or, alternatively, not be legitimately deductible against the income of the company providing that car. For clarification of that point I will refer the matter to the Treasurer, who I expect ultimately will refer it to the Commissioner of Taxation, and I will supply Senator Ray with an answer as soon as I am able to do so.

—My question is directed to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate. It relates to a statement made by Senator Button in the Senate on 22 September this year with regard to public duty and private interests of members of parliament, in which he said that he would refer to the Standing Orders Committee for consideration whether the registration system should be compulsory or voluntary. Is it the intention of the Government that the Standing Orders Committee should report on that matter before the Senate further considers the motion?

—I do not recall the statement made on 22 September, but I am certainly aware that the matter of declaration of pecuniary interests will be discussed by the Standing Orders Committee. However, the Government has come down with a proposal, and the proposal has been put to the Senate. We will be debating the matter as soon as we can, at which time Senator Townley and other senators will be able to express their views as to whether such declarations should be voluntary, private or otherwise. It may be that at that stage Senator Townley will want to move that the matter be referred to the Standing Orders Committee.
—I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that the motion that has been moved by the Government provides that registration will be public and that it will be compulsory?

—It is certainly Government policy and the Government's intention that such registration should be public-to the extent that the ministerial declarations have been made public-and compulsory. We do not believe that all the fine details of that type should be made public; but, to the extent that they are made public, they should be. However, that is a matter to be debated by the Senate and the House of Representatives-the Parliament as a whole-and we will see what comes out of that.

—Is the Minister for Social Security aware that there are problems in the St Kilda office of the Department of Social Security since the discovery that asbestos has been found in the building? Does the Minister consider that this is hazardous for staff or for the public visiting the office? Has the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association been consulted on behalf of its members? What action has been taken to ensure that proper safety standards for staff and visitors to the departmental office will apply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that asbestos has been discovered in the St Kilda office of the Department of Social Security. A patch of the ceiling on the first floor of the building was damaged. The sealant had cracked and asbestos was discovered. It was found during the repair of the damage that asbestos had fallen into the working area. The particles that had fallen contained a mixture of vermiculite, asbestos and cement. At that time the staff in the office contacted the Assistant Secretary of the ACOA. They had a meeting of union members in the office at that time. The staff were granted short term leave to allow them to consult with management and State headquarters. Eventually they reaffirmed that they would not work under these circumstances. After considerable consultation the staff finally requested that arrangements be made to relocate all staff, and that happened.

ANSWER.PARA: At the moment a team of experts is looking at the problem. They will totally clean the whole of the first floor of the building. The Department is seeking alternative accommodation but as the St Kilda area is one of high activity- particularly high unemployment-considerable efforts have had to be made to ensure that people in need are carefully looked after by the Department. The Department will ensure first of all that the staff are working in safe conditions and secondly that the clients of the Department are served well by the Department. Thirdly, in order to achieve both of these things, we will continue to consult with the ACOA and relative unions about this and other matters to ensure that everybody is happy. It is a difficult situation but unfortunately more and more asbestos is being found in particularly older buildings and it is creating-as everyone knows-a problem not only in Melbourne and St Kilda but also in Canberra and other places.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN ELECTORAL OFFICE EDUCATION AND ENROLMENT CAMPAIGN

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. I refer to yesterday's statement by the Special Minister of State concerning the Australian Electoral Office education and enrolment campaign. On page 7 of the statement the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: To assist the department's relating to youth the Government has decided to undertake a research project which will thoroughly investigate the views and attitudes of youth on such matters as the education system, employment training opportunities, income support, employment expectations and government policies and programmes in these areas.

Can the Minister inform me whether it is true that officers of her Department, working in the office of Youth Affairs, have not been informed of such a research project? Does the Minister agree that such a research project would be viewed by some young people as extreme cynicism, given that the report entitled 'Creating Tomorrow Today', prepared by the Youth Affairs Council of Australia and funded under the previous Government by Federal funds, has only just been launched and has not yet had time to be seriously considered by anyone?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the latter part of Senator Haines's question, the report 'Creating Tomorrow Today' is currently being considered by officers within my Department. It is also being considered by officers within departments that have a complementary role with regard to youth, such as the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Senator Don Grimes, the Minister for Social Security. That report was the result of extensive consultation carried out by officers of the Office of Youth Affairs in co- operation with the various voluntary organisations throughout Australia that represent and have participation by young people. It is an extremely useful document. Not only is it currently being considered within the Government but also will it provide the basis for the agenda and topics to be considered at the first ever meeting of Ministers involved with youth affairs, to be held towards the end of November. So, the usefulness of that report is not in doubt. Everything that report contains will find its way into Government thinking and policy, not only at the Federal level but also at the State level.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I think that the exercise engaged in developing that report is different from the proposal to research youth attitudes, mainly in respect of youth attitudes to our parliamentary system, government policy and so on. One of the differences is that the report 'Creating Tomorrow Today' was concerned with the broadest possible consultation with youth about its circumstances, whereas the research that is currently being planned is much more specific and will research in a different way-not through broad based consultation but through a research project set up by a research organisation-specific attitudes in depth. So, I think that the results we will get from this specific research project will be different and will add to the picture of youth needs that we are starting to get through the activities of consultation with voluntary youth organisations. I have some more detailed information with regard to the particular research project to which Senator Haines's question referred, but I think that, rather than take the time of the Senate, I might pass that information to Senator Haines. If she wishes for further information, I will be happy to provide it to her.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not know what the supplementary information that the Minister has contains, but she certainly did not inform me whether officers of her Department in the Office of Youth Affairs have been informed of such a project. Nor did she say whether, if they have not been informed, it is because they will not be taking any part in it and that there was therefore no need to inform them.

—The honourable senator obviously has been misinformed. Not only are the officers of my Department aware of the proposed research project, but they have participated in discussions about what form it should take, in finding an appropriate research organisation to carry out the project and so on. That is the detailed information that I have here. But, as it would take some time to read out this information, I suggest that I make it available to Senator Haines.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs: Is it a fact that the International Red Cross has suspended its humanitarian activities in East Timor because the Indonesians have refused delegates access to all villages requiring assistance? Is it also a fact that the Indonesians will not allow International Red Cross to visit detainees? If these are facts, will the Minister undertake to approach the Minister for Foreign Affairs and ask him to use his influence with the Indonesian Government to allow the International Red Cross to operate freely in East Timor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen newspaper reports to the effect stated by Senator Robertson. The latest information from the Minister for Foreign Affairs that I have to hand on this question is dated 30 September, so it may be that something is out of date in the light of the events of the last few days. If that is so-and I will check the matter further-I will certainly let the honourable senator know. On the information available to me as at 30 September, I can say this: On 26 September the International Committee of the Red Cross representative in Jakarta denied media reports that the ICRC had been refused access to East Timor. He said that the ICRC still had access to the territory, although with significant restrictions of movement on the main island. He did, however, confirm that the ICRC had not yet resumed relief operations on the main island due to limitations on ICRC delegates imposed by the Indonesian authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: He added that these matters were under negotiation in Jakata and that the ICRC was willing to resume its assistance program as soon as ICRC criteria were met. Meanwhile the Red Cross was continuing its food and medical program on Atauro Island where alleged Fretilin sympathisers are held. The Australian Government attaches importance to humanitarian assistance that the ICRC and other relief agencies have been able to extend to the people of East Timor for this reason: Australia has contributed a total of $6.2m towards the ICRC's operation in East Timor, including a grant of $1m in June this year. The Australia Government hopes that, as a result of the negotiations now taking place, the ICRC will be allowed not only to continue its relief operations on Atauro, its involvement in family reunions, mailing, tracing and protection activities, but also to extend its relief operations to the mainland of East Timor where necessary and to expand its program of visits to detention centres.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before Question Time continues, I think I should say something about the comments made earlier by Senator Chipp. Having in mind the expression by Senator Chipp, I remind the Senate that the exercise of the freedom of speech guaranteed to, and fundamental to the rights of, members of the House of Representatives and the Senate also carries with it considerable responsibility. I am fully aware that the Joint Committee on Parliamentary Privilege is considering the matter. I am also aware of expressions of public concern as to the use of the privilege as it sometimes relates to private citizens. As President of the Senate responsible for the conduct of the chamber, I ask all honourable senators on both sides of the House to keep in mind the proper propriety of proceedings at all times. I also point out, in fairness to those who are anxious to ask questions, that a large number of supplementary questions have been asked today. I ask that honourable senators respect the rights of other senators when asking supplementary questions.

—Mr President, my rising again in no way implies any disagreement with the earlier part of your comments. I am sorry to take yet another question. I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether he is aware that Queensland has, for a long time, had a National-Liberal Party Coalition Government. Does he agree that in the State of Queensland population growth has been well above the national average for many years and that Queensland has become a magnet for people from the other States? Does he agree that the growth in population in Queens- land has arisen from both a higher birth rate and a strong migration flow from all other States? Does he agree that over the last three years there has been a very substantial creation of new jobs in Queensland , whereas there has been a loss of jobs in the States of New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia? Is he aware that Queensland has a rate of unemployment which is well below the national average and which is well below the level of unemployment which is suffered in the Labor State of South Australia, in the Labor State of New South Wales and in the Labor ruled State of Western Australia? Bearing in mind all of these obvious advantages which are enjoyed by Queensland and the disadvantages which are suffered by those States which have Labor governments, does he agree that the misuse of statistics that he indulged in in the earlier part of Question Time was a real abuse of this Question Time?

—I am well aware of the fact that the traditional excuse for unemployment in Queensland is both the interstate migration and the high birth- rate-the high rate of population growth in Queensland. Without reflecting on whatever validity that excuse may at some time or other have had, it certainly does not account for the massive increase in unemployment of 65 per cent-well above the national average, more than double the increase in South Australia- which has occurred in Queensland in the last 12 months. It may have accounted for unemployment to some extent in the past in the State of Queensland. It cannot possibly account for the enormous increase that has occurred in the last year.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before debate on the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill, the Archives Bill and the Copyright Amendment Bill was interrupted at noon, I had spoken on what the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill does. I had expressed very grave disappointment that the Government had seen fit to abandon its election undertakings to implement the whole of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on freedom of information and that it had proceeded only some distance in expanding on provisions in the Freedom of Information Act Bill. I welcomed the extent to which the Government had gone in so doing. I pointed out the two salient features about which the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, and other spokesmen, particularly spokesmen such as Mr Lionel Bowen and Dr Blewett in the other place, had been so vigorous-namely, the abolition of conclusive certificates which stand as a blot on the present law of freedom of information in this country and the failure to take up the powers which were hoped to be given to the Commonwealth Ombudsman. These were gross failures of the election undertakings of the Government which were clearly expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly intend to move amendments-the same amendments which Senator Gareth Evans moved some two years ago-during the Committee stage.

I know that some of my amendments will not succeed because the present Opposition has not changed its past view on conclusive certificates but I believe that there is a reasonable hope that some of my amendments will succeed. I hope that the Government will then have a good hard look at the problems which these amendments raise and that it will go back to its initial good intentions. I point out that, when the debate took place on the Bill in the House of Representatives two years ago on 23 February, Dr Neal Blewett-who is now a Minister-after pointing out for the benefit of the then Opposition that, if better access to freedom of information was given it would improve political debate and would help to keep Ministers on their toes, had this to say about political principle:

However, I hope that we are supporting the improvements to this Bill not simply for that reason but also because we do consider that the needs of Parliament and the community can both be served by more effective freedom of information legislation than is offered by the Government in this Bill. Let me say that in the not too distant future when we are in Government I hope that we will be able to remember that principle because, as I have suggested tonight, one of the great temptations is the fears that governments have that somehow they will lose authority by giving information, a form of power, to a wider audience.

We know now that that principle has not been sustained. We know indeed that the community is not to be given the facilities, in particular the facilities for the working of the Ombudsman in the monitoring role, examining the legislation, helping people and appearing to represent them if necessary for them on matters of principle if they are involved in testing the refusal to give information. These are not the principles which, although espoused by one of the leading spokesmen of the then Opposition, the present Government will maintain. Unfortunately this new Government has lost authority because it is not willing to share that information with the community.

I do not propose to go into any more detail about the amendments which I will move subsequently. But I say this about one question which I think arises: It is often said by spokesmen that somehow ministerial responsibility can be interfered with by the Freedom of Information Act. That argument took place when the original Bill was before us. Those who opposed the Bill, particularly the public servants, were very ready to maintain that somehow the Westminster system would be damaged. I want to read from an article which is relevant certainly to one amendment which I do not think will have great support but which I stand by. I refer to an article by Professor John D. McManus on freedom of information in Canada, where freedom of information has taken interesting turns. Perhaps Canada in some ways is now slightly behind Australia. Speaking about the argument, he said:

The essence of the argument made on this point in the Green Paper and, indeed, by many federal and provincial spokesmen before and since, was that judicial review of decisions to deny access to government records would be inconsistent with the constitutional convention of ministerial responsibility. This was, and remains, an interesting exercise in political rhetoric. Although there appears to be no merit whatsoever in the claim of inconsistency, governments have attempted to defend their tradition of refusing inconvenient disclosures under the guise of preserving our Parliamentary heritage. The constitutional reality, however, is that the convention of ministerial responsibility has nothing to do with the tradition of non-disclosure. On the contrary, the convention asserts that Ministers of the Crown are responsible individually and collectively to the Legislature for the administration of the executive branch of government. The historical significance of a principle rendering the Ministers of the Crown accountable to the Legislature is obvious: it is also obvious, of course, that with the rise of political parties and acceptance of the principle of party solidarity, the accountability of the Cabinet to the Legislature is more a matter of form than substance. Thus, more cynical observers argue that ' ministerial responsibility' is a shopworn constitutional myth and that one of the very compelling arguments in favour of freedom of information laws in parliamentary jurisdictions is that it would restore a measure of that very kind of accountability that was originally secured by the convention of ministerial responsibility.

I believe that puts the argument very well. It is relevant to the continuance and insistence by the Government and, unfortunately, most of my colleagues on this side, in regard to leaving the conclusive certificates entirely in the hands of a ministerial decision. It also applies to one other amendment which I shall move, but which I do not think will be successful at this time, to enable the Ombudsman to look into ministerial acts as well. I will separate that from the other amendments relating to the Ombudsman's powers. I believe, as I have for many years, that there is no sound basis for the removal in general terms of the Ombudsman's powers to look into ministerial decisions and certainly not in relation to freedom of information and the disclosure of documents. I trust that the amendments I will move will test the Government. If some are carried I think that will test the Government even more as to whether it can get back to a genuine spirit of co-operation in this matter.

I want to say finally in this speech on the second reading debate that I believe we are now in a process of examination of the workings of the Act. I recognise that the Australian Democrats have a number of amendments which I think have a relatively small compass and which are probably quite justified but , on the other hand, I think there is a difficulty. In my amendments I have taken only two of the major areas where the Government has palpably fallen down in its obligations. I have no doubt that when we examine the operation of this Act at the end of a year or so we will find that public servants have overused, misused and tended to rely on the vagueness of some of the exemptions. I hope that all these matters will then go before committees of the Senate and that those committees will do a fresh examination to see how the Act is working and come up with recommendations. Irrespective of whether some of my amendments and those of the Democrats succeed in being passed today-I welcome the fact that they are being put before the Parliament today-I trust that these matters will be considered very carefully by those who examine the operations of the Act and have the facts before them as presented in the reports of the Attorney-General's Department, the Ombudsman and the other departments. Those reports will be available to Parliament to see how all the workings of the Act are operating.

Members of the public have suggested a number of improvements to other matters contained in the Bill. I referred before to the statements by the Library Association of Australia which has taken a consistent, very considerable and useful interest in the operation and the formation of the Bill. I referred earlier to a point made in its submission. It is this:

Another point of contention is the classification of exempt documents (Ss.11.12 ). Once documents are declared exempt they remain so until they may become available under the open access provisions of the Archives Act 1983. As before, we submit that the legislation should make provision for periodic review of exempt documents (to enable their release before 30 years has elapsed), or for a different classification when their exemption is first decided.

In contradistinction to the United States of America, where there are some provisions for the review of classifications, I am afraid that we have not got that far here. We are now likely to have refusals that will stand on the record in regard to documents that ought to be released in, say, five, six or 10 years time and not be reviewed. I trust that this whole matter of the classification of documents will be one of the things that are looked at early by this Government. I hope it will look also at the existing secrecy provisions which are immense in number and inconsistent in nature and which the Senate Committee report pointed out needed considerable review. I trust also that the Government will be proceeding with the idea of indexing Government documents so that it will be easier for people to know what records are held in government. With the use of computers and other machines, I trust that, in the future, the availability of government documents will be made easier for the public. It is all very much a matter of how this legislation operates. It is disappointing in a sense that the Act has so far not had a very great acceptance and that not many people have used it. I trust that the people of Australia will take a greater interest in it and make good use of it in the future. I support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The explanatory memorandum to the Archives Bill refers to the role of the Australian Archives in:

SPEECH.PARA: identifying and physically preserving records of administrative, community, cultural or educational value.

On the same page it refers to material in the custody of certain institutions being in general terms outside the scope of the legislation. In this regard it refers to the National Library of Australia. It is to do with some of the cultural records of the country, perhaps presently in the possession of the National Library that I wish to comment. The Library has certainly honoured its charter and commitment in that it has collected quite large quantities of film, records and tape. It is in relation to the preservation of these that I wish to address myself today. It is not necessary to go through all the newspaper cuttings, articles and speeches of recent times about this part of the National Library. An article in the Bulletin only recently referred to the crisis at the archives. To spend time today arguing about whether the National Library has spent adequate resources on this section of its activities probably does not get us anywhere. The Library says that it has not had sufficient funds to allocate more than it has to the preservation of these articles, and government clearly has not heard the call to identify the need and give more moneys to it. I wonder whether it is necessary to devise a system whereby funding is made available directly for the purpose of preserving film records, tapes and other precious records so that it does not get confused in the Library's funds with the supply and preservation of books and other things.

I am particularly glad to have the opportunity to raise the matter today because of the article in this morning's Canberra Times, headed 'Library to consider disciplining archivist'. It refers to a letter which Mr Peter Burgis, a sound archivist at the Library, sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in which he publicly criticised the state of the Library's sound recording collection. Mr Burgis is also the Australian Capital Territory Branch President of the International Association of Sound Archivists. He is eminent in his field and I think we should hear from him and know what he thinks about the state of the collection and what should be done about it. I appreciate, of course, the role of a public servant in not criticising his employer and I agree with that as a principle, but this is a grey area and a difficult one, and I would be disappointed indeed if the National Library Council took any form of disciplinary action. Rather, it should hear Mr Burgis as somebody who has something to say on something about which all Australians should be concerned and to which all Australians should want to see a solution found.

The fact is that many precious records of our history have been lost because they have not been stored properly and have not been preserved. The Library, luckily, now has many records. Jim Davidson, the ABC Dance Band leader, in his will gave his whole record collection to the National Library. When I was last at the Library the collection had not been classified, properly numbered and identified. A lot of work has to be done. It is very clear indeed that sufficient resources are not being allocated for the purpose of properly classifying and preserving all these records. The Library can quite properly say that it has increased its funding. In a Press statement it indicated that its funding had increased by 172 per cent and that is true. But it depends, of course, from what base one starts in determining whether it is an adequate sum. As I said, I think that to spend time arguing about that aspect is pointless. We need solutions to the problem. Some people suggest that the responsibility for film and sound archives should be taken away from the National Library and given to a special institution. There is certainly a lot to be said for that suggestion. There is some suggestion that the costs of doing so, administratively, are out of proportion to the size of the operation and that maybe under the management of the Library is still the appropriate place for it to be. I think it is necessary for the funding to be separately identified so that there cannot be confusion about what funds are in fact available.

Records exist that ought to be available to people. I have been involved with the Print Handicapped Radio of the Australian Capital Territory organisation in Canberra. It is particularly interested in seeking from the Library copies of old radio plays so that they can be played on its radio system for people who are interested in hearing them. That organisation has offered to help with the copying but it has not been able to get the material it wants because the Library does not have available the necessary resources. A letter which was written by the Chairman of the Council of the National Library to Mrs Jill Southwell, Secretary of the Print Handicapped Radio of the Australian Capital Territory organisation, dated 9 February 1983 stated:
I have received your letter . . . dealing with difficulties experienced by Print Handicapped Radio Stations in obtaining access to material in the Sound Recording Collection of the National Library.
The letter went on to state:

As you will know from previous discussion and correspondence, the establishment and development of the Sound Recording Collection is a matter in which the National Library Council has taken a close interest, as indeed it also has in the provision of services to the Handicapped. The Council recognises that much needs to be done in both these areas of service. However, it is confident that, not only is the Library making the best possible headway within its present resource, but the Library is also putting every effort into obtaining the additional resources which would enable the services to be developed more speedily.

The thrust of the letter is that the Library certainly believes that it is doing the best it can but it does not have the resources to deal adequately with the matter. The same group took up the matter with the Commonwealth Ombudsman and received a letter from the Ombudsman dated 23 August 1983 which, in part, says:

Oral advice provided by the Principal Librarian has confirmed the earlier advice to you by both the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and the National Library Council that the main barrier to access is the Library's inability, in terms of staff and equipment, to service PHR's request.

The evidence is that what Mr Burgis says is right-more resources are needed. He is crying out for help, in a sense, to ensure that adequate resources are made available. The Library itself, in a Press statement dated 18 September, when referring to the facilities, said that this is in spite of the fact that a disproportionate amount of recent increases in the Library's total budget is being spent on the film archives in preference to other sections of the Library. It goes on to justify and explain the amount that has been spent, but it is all too little for what needs to be done. We have an obligation to those generations who will follow us to see that we do better than we have done in the past.

There has been some argument about the siting of the Archive. My view is that it should have a separate building in Canberra and that it should have the proper sound recording studios where copies can be made of these precious records. I use the word 'records' in the widest sense. It should have a shop from which copies of songs and speeches can be sold. I do not think there would be a tourist coming to Canberra who would not be interested in seeing and buying some of these things so as to have as a memento of the occasion. The Library also has old gramophone records and so on that could be displayed. It could be a magnificent centre. The real benefit of that would be that it would encourage other people to donate their collections and the records which they have in their possession to this institution. Perhaps the Library should continue to deal with the administrative side of this-perhaps not. What we do not want to do is increase the bureaucratic costs of running it. We want the moneys that are available to be used for the purpose of preservation.

There has been some discussion about whether the Archive should be located in Sydney or Melbourne. The mere fact that there is discussion about that makes it quite clear that it should stay in Canberra, the national capital. All things of this nature should be here. I could quote from many articles today-I would like to do so-but I think many people are aware of them. Today I wish to say to the National Library Council: Listen to Mr Burgis. Do not criticise him for what he has said. Co-operate with government in seeing that the very best endeavour is put into preserving these treasures so that future generations can have them. I think that by 1988 there will be a lot of interest in the material we have. I rather fear that if we are not careful it will not have been classified and will not be available for people at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with the Copyright Amendment Bill which, I think, is extremely ill timed. It is not, I think, a piece of this Government's legislation. It has been in the machine for some considerable time. It has come to us, in my view, at a peculiarly inappropriate time. The Bill seeks to amend the Copyright Act to provide for delivery by broadcasting and television organisations of so-called ephemeral records to the Australian Archives. At present such ephemeral records are given to the National Library to be held by the National Film Archive. The question of the future of the National Film Archive is a matter for current consideration by the Government. It seems most peculiar, to put it mildly, that at this very time the Government should be pushing through legislation which removes some part-admittedly a small part-of the material that goes to the National Film Archive and gives it to a different organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: To make quite clear what we are talking about, I should explain that an ephemeral record-that includes a videotape, a film or a sound record-is a record made by a radio or television broadcaster for the sole purpose of broadcasting a copyright work or recording. Of course, they can broadcast it, with permission, but it must be destroyed within a year unless it is turned over to a proper archive. Before the record can be accepted by the Australian Archives it must be classified as being of exceptional documentary character. I only want to refer to films and videotapes. If they are truly of an exceptional documentary character, I cannot understand why they are to be taken away from the National Film Archive and given to the Australian Archives. That seems to me a peculiar step. Ultimately it may be shown to be justified after a full investigation of the future of the National Film Archive, but I believe that is improbable. Certainly this should not be done in advance of that study and those decisions.

I believe Australia can afford only one properly endowed national film archive. Even if it were possible to afford more, the importance of having a single focus for Australia's film heritage-this situation applies in other countries-is obvious. I do not dispute for a moment that the Australian Archives has a right- it is proper for it to have such a right-to have records in film form when dealing with records as such. When one is dealing with creative or documentary films, whether made by film or television companies, whether they are on tape or film, they are all part of our film culture and should be in a single archive which by its very nature must be the National Film Archive. I know this is under study by the Government at the moment. I merely wish to make some remarks about how this should be set up to guide the Government's faltering steps in the right direction. It seems that there is some confusion about where it is going.

I do not think anyone these days would dispute the importance of a proper national film archive. We have been very neglectful of our extraordinary cultural heritage in the past. I give one example: Australia's first great film maker, Raymond Longford, made 27 feature films. Only four of them have survived in the national archive. We must tackle these problems of preserving our heritage.

Our present National Film Archive as part of the National Library has great problems. It has poor access for people who want to use it. It is very badly underfunded which, of course, contributes to the poor access. It is poorly catalogued and it is not keeping pace with the necessity to transfer on to modern stock the old nitrate stock which is deteriorating very fast. We have an urgent need to preserve and give proper access to this vital part of our national heritage. I believe it is now time that the National Film Archive should be separate from the National Library. This relationship was largely accidental. The Library took on the various tasks when no one else was willing or able to do them and as part of its role it has not only a library but also a film archive and a sound archive, which Senator Reid was talking about a moment ago, and a painting collection. The question is whether these are still appropriate for the National Library or whether they should be hived off to more responsive bodies. I do not believe that the National Library is an appropriate setting for the National Film Archive. I do not believe the management of the Library has understood or will understand the nature and needs of a National Film Archive, nor is it reasonable to expect it to do so.

There should be a commitment by this Government, as soon as practicable, to make the National Film Archive a separate statutory body, at the latest by 1986. Of course, it will take time because of the heavy reliance on the present infrastructure of the National Library. In the meantime, the National Film Archive should be given an operational charter in the form, I suggest, of a Cabinet resolution, with its own governing board, representative of the film and television community and with executive power. It should be attached administratively either to the Department of Home Affairs and Environment or to the Australian Film Commission. That is a matter of organisational structure on which I do not express an opinion. Obviously, it should be studied, but they seem to me to be the only two possible short term options.

As I said earlier, the National Film Archive has been grossly understaffed. The present staff of nine should be increased over the next three years at least four-fold with, of course, appropriate regradings and restructuring. I give, as an example only, typical figures but the budget should be increased to at least $1.5m next year and probably $3m a year by 1985-86. That is the sort of order of expense which is necessary if we are to preserve this vital part of our national heritage. I suggest that this National Film Archive, when set up as an independent body, should have a one-line budget with power and incentive to generate income through revenue, sponsors and donations.

The question of location is a very difficult one. I heard Senator Reid rather naturally speak strongly in favour of a continuation of residence in Canberra. The problem with Canberra, as far as the film community is concerned, is that it is neither accessible nor, I submit, appropriate. There will be deep problems deciding between Sydney and Melbourne but one of the first tasks of the new board of the National Film Archive should be to work out where the headquarters should be and how adequate access can be provided in other centres.

The role of the new National Film Archive-it would be the first body whose prime task would be as a film archive, not a sideline film archive-should be the co-ordinating body in Australia. It should be built up as a centre of preservation expertise. It should maintain comprehensive records of Australian productions and archival holdings generally. It should have a mandate to preserve a comprehensive range of Australian film and television productions. It must have the power to resolve overlaps with other archival bodies to bring about greater co-ordination and standardisation, and, of course, it should represent Australia internationally in its field.

As a means to this, I suggest this new NFA board should promulgate for wide discussion on selection, acquisition preservation, access and other operational policies. I hope that with staff increases it will be able to lift the present restrictions on access by next year. I do not think it would be appropriate for it to have its own cinematheque outlet. That would be expensive and in my view unwarranted. An organisation with which I am associated, the Australian Film Institute, is willing, able and appropriate to perform this role in consultation with the Film Archive.

I mention gently that I suspect the advice going to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) will come exclusively from the National Library of Australia and, not surprisingly, it will fight very strongly and very understandably to retain this part of its empire, even at a time when empire creation is becoming unfashionable and possibly inappropriate. I strongly suggest that the Minister get alternative advice from the Australian Film Commission, which cannot give it to him unless he asks for it. I think the Minister has the responsibility to look at all sides of this and not to stick with the status quo. It may be that if and when we set up this new independent National Film Archive-which we will have to do eventually, and the sooner the better-the problem of the sound archive might be solved by associating it with the Film Archive, but I express no opinion on that. I think that is one matter the Minister should look at.

As I have said, I think it is the Government's vital role and urgent task to see that there is proper preservation of and access to this vital part of our culture. I think that the Bill-it could be reversed later on but that would make it even more futile-which would pre-empt part of the access collection of the National Film Archive, should be deferred and considered again when the Government has decided what its policy is towards the National Film Archive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this debate and forgive them for all the point-scoring in which they have inevitably engaged. I can assure them that in their shoes I would have been even more vitriolic under the circumstances. I could hardly do anything else. On any view the Freedom of Information Amendment Bill is a major reforming measure in its own right, even though it does come only a year or so after the passage of the parent Freedom of Information Act. It picks up something like eleven major recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, made in its much referred to report, together with a considerable number of other changes to reflect the experience that has already been gleaned in the few short months of operation of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The affirmation that this Bill amounts to is a very substantial one of commitment by the present Government to the principles of freedom of information . It is an affirmation that we have already made perfectly clear by the very many administrative arrangements we have continued to put into place to make the freedom of information legislation more effective since we have come into office . It is an affirmation that we have also made very publicly by our direction as an executive government back in May that the Act be administered from that date as though the present legislation were already in effect, notwithstanding that it was not anticipated that the legislation would be dealt with by this Parliament until well into the Budget session.

It may be overlooked in some of the Committee stage debate to follow-certainly it was largely overlooked in the second reading debate so far-that the Bill contains many significant improvements to the parent legislation. It will allow the public a greater right to access for a start to prior documents. Senator Durack was kind enough to acknowledge this, and I appreciate his doing so. It is significant that no time barriers will now apply where an individual seeks access to his own records. It is significant that other records, generally up to five years old, will now be brought within the Act. It is significant that a document older than five years, although this was essentially the subject matter of the previous legislation, will also now be more readily, or at least as readily, available as before to the extent that it can be shown that access to it is reasonably necessary to a proper understanding of one of the documents that is now primarily available. There is a larger class of those by virtue of the amendments in this Act.

It is significant that we are recasting the administrative procedures so as to vest the more sensitive areas of jurisdiction in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal itself rather than in any separate, specialist, rather idiosyncratic little documents review tribunal that was the subject matter of the last Government's legislation. It is particularly significant in this respect that, even though conclusive ministerial certificates remain, Ministers will be positively required under this Bill, if they are not going to accept the recommendatory decision of the Adminstrative Appeals Tribunal in an area of confidential information, to table in the Parliament statements of reasons for not accepting the recommendation in question. This is a way of ensuring a greater focus and a greater degree of accountability on those Ministers who may be minded cavalierly to ignore the recommendations of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which should have every considerable political effect.

It is significant again that a new public interest test will apply to the exemption of documents affecting the financial or property interests of the Commonwealth, to documents concerning tests, examinations and audits, the review of agency functions and the management interests of the Commonwealth. It is significant that that new public interest test will also apply to claims that a Commonwealth-State document is exempt which up until now has not been subject to a similar constraint of that kind, a recommendation that was very strongly put by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It is significant, and should be satisfying to the States that otherwise might be upset about the extension of the force of the legislation in this respect, that States will now have a formal right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against decisions that their documents be disclosed.

It is significant that the legislation is being strengthened to make it clear that purely factual documents from the Cabinet and Executive Council area are exempt. There is more than just a nudge in that direction, as was the case in the parent legislation. We now have clear statutory language to ensure it. It is particularly significant, finally, that there be a provision now explicitly made for a progressive reduction in the time for compliance by departments and agencies with the freedom of information legislation requests from the present 60 days to a target of 30 days by 1 December 1986. I hope that when one goes quickly through a recitation of some of the major provisions of that kind it will be appreciated that what we are doing here is more than simply tidying up one or two loose ends. We are significantly extending the scope and the reach of the freedom of information legislation because as a government we are very much committed to effective access to government information.

That much said, I have to acknowledge, I suppose, that it is inevitable that I should have been accused, as I was by so many speakers in this debate, of a degree of hypocrisy, given that the legislation, as I have outlined it, falls short in some equally significant respects of recommendations of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee. I think they are only two of the seven deadly sins referred to by Senator Missen still left standing in respect of which penance has to be paid by those of us who supported changes of this kind. But those two areas, of conclusive certificates and a greater role for the Ombudsman, are ones in respect of which the Government has decided that, at least at this stage, it is not appropriate to make further extensions of the reach of the Freedom of Information Act.

To the extent that there can be quoted against me, as there were by, I think, almost every speaker who rose to his or her feet, contrary statements by me in times in the more distant and the more recent past, I guess that I simply have to bear that with such fortitude as I can command. I offer, I suppose, a couple of factors in mitigation. One is that I had a fairly clear-eyed perception as to the likely prospects of some of these measures in opposition, as Senator Durack has been kind enough, for one, to remind me; and I do not think it can be said, as another speaker suggested, that I was carried away by my own rhetoric. I may well have been carried away by my own optimism and aspirations, because there is often in government a gap between the aspirations of individual Ministers and the achievements that they can chalk up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was just youthful enthusiasm.

—It is certainly not youthful any more, and it is becoming rapidly less enthusiastic. But I cannot entirely forebear from making the rather churlish observation that I made at the second reading stage-that at least in the case of the present Government there is both aspiration and achievement of some significant kind, albeit that the gap between the two may on occasion remain visible. I suppose that the other point that might well be made by some of my colleagues, if not by myself, is that I am hard enough to live with at the best of times; if I did not get a knockback occasionally, I would be quite impossible. So I appreciate those members of this Senate who have contributed, in that respect, to making me a better and warmer human being, if not Attorney- General.

SPEECH.PARA: Having taken in this respect the major steps that we have in further liberalising the legislation, we look forward not to resting on our laurels. They are, as I have been trying to indicate, very considerable laurels in this legislation. We regard freedom of information legislation as properly a dynamic instrument not just of government policy but rather of the democratic process itself. We shall keep this legislation closely under review and we shall certainly be happy to encourage and to accommodate the full-scale review of the legislation by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs , which is anticipated for 1985, three years after the commencement of the legislation. It is wholly proper that this sort of legislation be subjected to very close review and approached continually by governments with a broad and open mind as to what it might accomplish in improving the quality of government. That is the commitment we maintain to this legislation.

I come to the other Bills in the package before us. The Archives Bill is a very major piece of reforming legislation in its own right-so major that it has been in the pipeline since 1978, I think, with successive governments or successive Ministers in charge of it, in one way or another, neglecting its passage. That is unfortunate, because it is important and it has been important for a long time that the Australian Archives be put on a proper statutory basis and that the law covering the control and management of archives be carefully co- ordinated with the law covering freedom of information. That is what is accomplished by this Bill. It is an important piece of legislation. I am glad to note that it has not been opposed in any way as to its basic principles by Senator Martin, on behalf of the Opposition, or by any other speaker. To the extent that particular matters of detail have arisen in the course of discussion , as they have particularly in the context of the National Film Archive question , and to the extent that questions of legislative significance arise they can perhaps be dealt with at the Committee stage.

Finally, in regard to the Copyright Amendment Bill, I did not understand any speaker to have any fundamental objections to the basic principles of this piece of remedial legislation, to the extent that it was involved in tidying up particular things that had gone wrong or needed attention in the past. Problems were raised by Senator Hamer about the implications of this legislation for the current public controversy about the National Film Archive. I think perhaps there has been a little misunderstanding about the effect of the Copyright Amendment Bill. It is certainly designed to enable, as the second reading and the Bill itself make clear, broadcasting and television organisations to deposit with the Australian Archives rather than the National Library so-called ephemeral records for Berne Convention Copyright purposes, and that clearly is of some symbolic significance at least, particularly given the circumstances of the current dispute. But it will also have been noticed that the second reading speech makes it clear that we are talking here basically only about fundamental legal relationships, not necessarily about the de facto care and management of such records. It is in fact proposed, so far as this Bill is concerned, that material so lodged with the Archives will be lodged in turn by the Archives, for the moment anyway, with the National Library of Australia, where they will be kept together with similar material from a variety of other sources.

None of this is to foreclose the ongoing debate or review about the proper role of the National Film Archive, whether it should be moved out of the National Library and become part of the Australian Archives or whether it should be established as a separate statutory instrumentality in its own right and, if so, where in turn it should physically be located. Clearly, as Senator Hamer has said, the current disputation about the National Film Archive has rather overtaken this itself rather archival Bill which has been around for a considerable number of years, I believe, and has been overtaken by recent events . A major review is currently taking place under the direction of the Government involving, in particular, the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, but other elements of the Executive Government as well. In the event that that review produces recommendations for legislative changes that are different from those accomplished in this piece of really consequential legislation, of course there will be separate legislation at a future time. Nothing in this legislation is to be regarded as, I repeat, foreclosing that debate.

I think with those remarks I can welcome the advent of the Committee stage, which I hope, given the time, can be rather expeditiously dispatched so that we can complete the debate on these Bills by the time we adjourn this afternoon.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Committee's recommendations which are now embodied in this first group of proposed amendments go much further than that. They contemplate a significantly expanded role for the Ombudsman, a central role in the actual on- the-ground practical administration of the whole Act. There are five elements in these proposals. Briefly, they are as follows:

The first element in the proposal is the creation of a separate administrative unit within the Ombudsman's office and the creation of a deputy Ombudsman for freedom of information. The second element in the proposal is the extension of the Ombudsman's ordinary function of investigation and conciliation to enable him to investigate as well ministerial decisions.
I point out that that is not in the amendment that I have moved. He went on:

The third element in the proposed equation is the giving to the Ombudsman of a role as general counsel for applicants appearing on their behalf before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The fourth element in the equation gives the Ombudsman a specific role as adviser to departments and agencies to assist them in working out the scope and extent of their obligations under the Bill. The fifth and last element in the proposal gives to the Ombudsman a specific power to monitor and criticise the way in which the legislation is operating and to report to the Parliament. The whole range of functions, both executive and legislative, that I have outlined is not able to be conducted by him, as at present. It is our belief that they ought to be.

Then, during the course of that debate, Senator Gareth Evans placed in the record a certain statement which is very useful in regard to the administrative implications of freedom of information for the Ombudsman. I will not read it but I refer honourable senators to pages 3248 and 3249 of the Senate Hansard of 12 June 1981. It appears as though facts have since indicated that the very much smaller call on the need for the Freedom of Information Act and, consequently, the need for the Ombudsman to be involved gives strength to those judgments which he then made.

I believe that it is terribly important in regard to the use of this Act that the Ombudsman be used as much as possible in the conciliating role but also where there are questions of principle arising and where there are matters where it is necessary to test before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal the refusals by a Minister or a department to make disclosure of a document. These matters ought to be properly dealt with and counsel may need to be employed. The Ombudsman himself or most likely counsel would then appear and make these representations. People would therefore not give up and matters would not be left to be decided at some later stage. I believe that each of these actions as far as the Ombudsman is concerned will be useful facilities. I trust that they will have the support of the Committee and that they will be carried.

(ii) informs or has informed the Tribunal, either before or in the course of the proceeding for the review of the decision, that the agency or the Minister, as the case requires, does not intend, or does not any longer intend, to refuse access to the document for the reason referred to in sub-paragraph (i),

then, for the purposes of the review by the Tribunal of that decision, this Act has effect as if sub-section 12 (2), or that sub-section as so modified, as the case requires, had not been enacted.'.''.

This amendment would add a new sub-clause (2) to clause 29. It amends section 58 of the parent Act in such a way as to empower the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to give access to prior documents, that is, those created now before five years old in the case of non-personal documents-where the decision-maker does not rely on the prior document ground of refusal. The point is best explained by reference to the decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which has prompted this amendment, that is, in the case of Witherford and the Department of Foreign Affairs. The Tribunal in that case held that the Freedom of Information Act does not enable the Tribunal to order that an applicant be given access to a document which is a prior document. This is so even where the Minister or the agency in possession of the document, acting in accordance with Government policy on the administration of the Act in accordance with the spirit of it rather than the strict letter, places no reliance on the fact that the document is a prior document under section 12 (2) of the present Act.

It often happens that an agency, in other words, will not want to take the ground that the document is a prior document but will want to take some other ground or to exempt a part of a document on some ground but is otherwise prepared to release the document. We have a situation where the Administrative Appeals Tribunal so far has thrown up its hands and said that once the document is in the prior document zone it is not empowered to resolve controversies of that kind and order, against the agencies wishes, the release of the document because of the inapplicability of the particular other exemption that is relied on. This clause makes it possible for that kind of an exercise to be undertaken by the Tribunal. The Government believes that that is consistent with the intention lying behind the way the Act should operate and be administered. That particular technical barrier to rationality which the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has perceived should be torn down. That is the effect of this amendment . I hope it attracts the support of the Committee.

I indicated in my speech that we appreciate that quite some detailed negotiations have to take place to effect the innovation that the Government wants to have in the area of parliamentary and court records. However, I reiterate the request that, as soon as possible, whatever determination is made become an amendment to what will by then be the Archives Act rather than that these arrangements should be left in regulations.

On the second point, the matter of clause 40 (4), there is reference to the shortening of time that the Australian Archives has to respond to a request for information. At present it is 90 days. These is an allowance, by regulation, that that period of 90 days might be shortened. If, after experience of the working of the new Act, the time is shortened from 90 days-if the shortened time is found to be practical-I would like the Attorney-General to give an undertaking that the Act will be amended accordingly so that this is not done just by regulation. These sorts of amendments are, of course, fairly common in statutory law. We get amendments in omnibus form from time to time. I seek from the Attorney an indication that the Government is alert to that request and will accede to it as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
