DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Northern Territory Criminal Code-Funding of Job Scheme for the Handicapped

PROCTEXT.PARA: Northern Territory Criminal Code-Funding of Job Scheme for the Handicapped
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be very brief as this Friday has been an extra sitting day for the Senate and there is the arrangement that the Senate will rise early to enable honourable senators to return to their homes interstate, that is, some of them, those who can, fortunately, travel. There are some documents, Mr President, that I should like incorporated in Hansard. I have referred them to the Government Whip, who has perused them and given his consent. I refer firstly to an article in the Australian of 10 September, in the Northern Territory section of the 'Focus on the Nation' page, the section which gives reports from the various States to the Australian. It was headed 'Trouble brewing over criminal code'. The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: The unseemly haste to pass the Territory's new criminal code, as well as extraordinary powers given by other hasty new legislation . . .
The article went on to say:
Mr Everingham promised extensive community input on the new code . . .

The plain truth of the matter is that this reporting is very misrepresenting and misinforming. I find it amazing for a paper such as the Australian to produce such an article. Usually the Australian, the national paper, is very open-minded and is extremely good in its reporting. The fact of the matter is that, over the two years since this legislation was brought into the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in 1981, there have been six drafts. There has been considerable community input, discussions with townspeople and with officers of the Department of Law. Aboriginal communities have been brought into the matter. Overall, through community input, many drafts were produced, until the seventh draft was passed in the Legislative Assembly, with amendments, in August.

There was no input from Aboriginal legal aid organisations, which was unfortunate. There was an input from the Northern Territory Law Society, but that was a week before the Bill was passed. It had been invited on many occasions. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the article headed 'Trouble brewing over the criminal code', and a letter from the Chief Minister for the Northern Territory telexed to the Australian on 14 September 1983. I must say that the editor of the Australian received it but did not print it.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
TROUBLE BREWING OVER CRIMINAL CODENorthern Territory
Jack Ellis

The unseemly haste to pass the Territory's new criminal code, as well as extraordinary powers given by other hasty new legislation to racing and gaming police, threaten to split the ruling Country Liberal Party.
Despite denials from the hierarchy, senior party officials are known to be furious at the Government's actions, claiming ministers are out of touch with popular feeling.
Chief Minister, Paul Everingham, has little time for anyone meddling in his Government's affairs and has no doubt given his detractors his usual blunt reply .
But with elections less than 10 months away and some turmoil in the party over pre-selections, even the high-flying Mr Everingham cannot dismiss the rumblings lightly.
Mr Everingham promised extensive community input on the new code, the subject of considerable controversy, with earlier drafts being withdrawn.
Instead, it was rushed through in a single Legislative Assembly sitting.

Already there are rumors of meetings between Government and the Law Society to correct mistakes which should have been sorted out in the House. Issues in the code such as the removal of the right to make an unsworn statement from the dock and removal of drunkenness as a defence in court actions were not fully debated.

In the same sitting, the Government amended racing and gaming legislation to give gaming inspectors the power to enter private homes without a warrant and with force if necessary. Reasonable suspicion is now the only ground necessary to invade a private dwelling.
One of the justifications for the move is that liquor inspectors and grain marketing inspectors already have such powers.

While remaining officially silent, police are upset and angry at the wide ranging powers being given to people they see as untrained and not subjected to extensively screening. Police must seek a warrant before entering premises.

Mr Everingham appears to see it as part of his job to make the unpopular decisions in the interests of his Territory. But some of his party officials believe these are the decisions of a man out of touch with the electorate.
They fear that keeping the ALP on the opposition benches for a further four years may not be as easy as many believed earlier this year.
The Editor,
The Saturday Australian,

Had your Northern Territory correspondent Jack Ellis been writing a company prospectus rather than a column for your edition of 10th September, he could well have found himself charged with fraud under Section 234 of the Northern Territory Criminal Code.

He wrote 'Mr Everingham promised extensive community input on the new Code . . . instead it was rushed through in a single Legislative Assembly Sitting.' Three further relevant points were made by correspondent Ellis:
1. Rumours of meetings with the N.T. Law Society to correct mistakes which should have been sorted out in the House.
2. No debate on removal of accused's right to make unsworn statements from the dock.
3. Removal of drunkenness as a defence in Court actions.
Because the Code is a very important Law in which the public should have confidence I respond as follows:

The first draft criminal code was tabled by me in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in March 1981. Since then, in an exhaustive process of public consultation the Territory Attorney-General (until November 1982 myself and latterly Jim Robertson) has held public seminars, consulted with community groups, spoken to individuals, clubs, associations and corporations. As a result , six drafts of the Code were tabled or introduced into the Assembly with numerous amendments over the period. Since June 1982 the drafts have followed largely the same format and have followed closely the Queensland Criminal Code.

The seventh and final 'draft code' was introduced in the August sittings of the N.T. Legislative Assembly. It naturally contained changes, some as a result of public comment, and also contained a large number of technical amendments, many of a minor nature.

For the sake of convenience and with the agreement of the Assembly, a new Bill (Serial 332) was introduced. This new Bill incorporated all of the proposed amendments contained in what would have been the amendment schedule of withdrawn Bill. Like the Bill Serial 332 which passed all stages during the August sittings, this amendment schedule would have likewise passed through the Assembly. This approach was taken to avoid the difficult and time-consuming task of dealing with the very large number of technical amendments. It is important to note that most of the amendments not of a technical nature stemmed directly from comments received from the Leader of the Opposition in the debate on the Code introduced in March.
This then is how the Code was 'Rushed through in a single legislative Assembly Sitting.'

As to 'rumours of meetings with the Law Society etc' Jim Robertson and I have made numerous public and private requests of the N.T. Law Society to comment on the Code as far back as March 1981. The Law Society (which to be fair, is not large) had not found itself able to do so. The Government a year or so ago arranged meetings between Law Society representatives and Government legal consultants such as Des Sturgess and Robin O'Regan (both prominent criminal lawyers in Queensland) who were involved in drafting the Code, to attempt to gain some input. It was not until a week before the August sittings that any written comment from the Law Society was received by Government. Following this, the Attorney-General met with representatives of the Law Society at their request to hear their views. The Territory Government welcomes representations of this nature and hopes the Law Society and the Territory Bar will take more interest in future in the formulation of laws, especially important documents such as the Code. No submissions were received from any Aboriginal Legal Aid Service although they were involved in the seminars.

Then we come to the claim that important issues were not fully debated. The first draft Code in 1981 made no provision for an unsworn statement from the Dock. Provisions relating to the effect on criminal liability of voluntary and involuntary intoxication were first brought to public notice in the draft Code tabled in March 1981. Indeed the provisions relating to intoxication are considerably watered down during the consultative process, as compared to the first draft, where intoxication was no defence at all. There have been debates and statements on the code in the Legislative Assembly on August 1981, November 1981, June 1982, August 1982, March 1983, May 1983 and August 1983.
On unsworn statements from the Dock I refer you to the comments of Justice Beach of the Victorian Supreme Court reported in ''The Age'' of 30 August 1983:

'What I do say is that serious consideration should be given to the abolition of unsworn statements. If an accused person wants to present evidence to a Jury, he should be required to do so in a manner that enables his account of any allegation he makes to be tested by cross-examination'.

As to intoxication, 80% of all violent crime in the Territory is alcohol related, and there is too much crime in the Territory, as reflected by our prison population. I refer you to the article on page 3 of the Australian on July 28, 1980, headlined 'Go West for Crime-Go North for Jail'.
The article reads in part ''the rate of imprisonment in the Northern Territory is three times higher than the national average, according to a survey released yesterday.

'. . . the results of the survey were published in the latest issue of ' Reporter', a journal of the Australian Institute of Criminology.' The N.T. Government, whilst committed to education and rehabilitation through the Alcohol and Drugs Bureau, is firmly resolved to deter people from abusing alcohol, especially where it leads to tragedy through violence.

The Northern Territory Criminal Code is the most substantial effort at Criminal Law Reform undertaken in Australia in half a century. It incorporates much of today's more liberal attitudes. For instance, the term rape has been erased from the statute books. A victim of sexual assault will not be cross-examined on previous sexual history, except with leave of the court. Homosexuality between consenting adult males in private is no longer an offence. The Code, in facing up to modern day problems includes a section on terrorism which of course is controversial, but has been commended for consideration by other States by the New South Wales Law Society Criminal Law Committee sitting as a committee of the Law Council of Australia, which said:

'We know of no other state which has legislation covering a similar area. In principle, these provisions do not seem inappropriate and it may well be that this area is deserving of consideration by other states'.

I also refer to the advances in relation to provocation, duress, coercion and diminished responsibility and in many instances these provisions extend what is the current law in the Territory and for that matter, Australia.
I would venture to say that consultative exercises in law-making undertaken in the Territory on the Code and notably also on our Liquor Legislation go far beyond similar efforts elsewhere.
Last week's column contains other material of a political nature.

No member of my Party, let alone its hierarchy, has spoken to me of the Criminal Code for months. As a conversational topic it was exhausted long ago. No representations were received by me or the responsible Minister on any section of the Gaming Bill from any member of the CLP.

Your correspondent is a former ALP candidate in Territory Legislative Assembly elections. As he points out, such elections are once again just around the corner. Could it be that not only politicians can be less than objective? Whilst Mr Ellis' statements will not wash in the Territory where people are only too well aware of the consultation that has gone on, I thought in the interests of accuracy and your wider readership to point out a few easily verifiable facts.
Yours sincerely, PAUL EVERINGHAM

TALK.START.PARA: —This prompted a question in the Senate, which was answered by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) on 21 September 1983. I should think , knowing the Attorney-General, that because of the misinformation that had been given to him he was rather startled into making a statement, I believe that a perusal of the file I have given him will throw a different light on the situation. There is a letter from the Chief Minister dated 23 September to the Attorney-General stating the facts of the situation. It suggests that an officer of the Department of Law in the Northern Territory, Mr Sturgess, be made available to brief the Attorney-General. I hope that the Attorney-General will accept that offer in an endeavour to have the situation straightened out completely. There is also a paper by the Chief Minister on the criminal code. I believe this information is important in order to give a clear indication of what this matter is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, might I say that over the last two years this matter has been given a great deal of airing in the community by officers of the Department of Law and there has been tremendous community input. I believe that the time has come for a review of the criminal code of the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory is still a type of frontier state. It has special problems that perhaps other States of Australia do not experience. I believe that this law will need some amendment over a period, as it is fairly extensive, but at least it is a code which should be received in good grace by the community, not only of the Northern Territory but of Australia as a whole. I seek leave to table the papers I have just briefly described, the letters and the paper on the criminal code.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to an article in today's Canberra Times headed 'Funding cuts stop job scheme for handicapped' which relates to cuts under the work independence program. The program has operated in the Australian Capital Territory since November 1981 and has been run by the Koomarri Industries group of the Handicapped Citizens Association in the Australian Capital Territory, at Fyshwick. Some 34 handicapped people have been trained under the program to the present time, 80 per cent of whom have obtained jobs in the community. The question really is: Is it a fact that this program will have to be discontinued? The program director has been dismissed by Koomarri because of lack of funds. Many people in this community are concerned about the program. It is an obviously successful program for the handicapped. Is the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) aware of what has happened? The Minister was undertaking a review of income support services for the disabled. I wonder whether he did initiate an inquiry into this program before cutting off the funds and whether something can be done to re-establish it, as it is clearly a successful program in the Australian Capital Territory that ought to be allowed to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The matters raised by Senator Kilgariff deserve a substantive reply and I propose to make one on the subject at some appropriate time in the next week or two, when I and my departmental officers have completed the review we are presently undertaking of the Northern Territory criminal code. It is appropriate, I believe, that the Commonwealth monitor closely what is going on in the Territory in this respect, notwithstanding the self-government Act under which the Territory now operates. There is a residual constitutional responsibility, of course, still vested in the Commonwealth and also a residual legislative responsibility under the terms of the self-government Act. We will be looking very closely at what our responsibilities might be in relation to this piece of legislation. I assure Senator Kilgariff that I was not startled into my answer in the Senate the other day. I have been familiar for quite a long time with what has been proposed with respect to the Northern Territory criminal code, although I was not familiar with the detail of the final version of the draft as it went through the Assembly. I was familiar enough, nonetheless, with the general concepts that seem to have been evident throughout the history of the drafting of this matter to be concerned at some of the reporting I had seen about the particular provisions of the code and I can assure the honourable senator that I retain that concern at this stage although I do not think this is the appropriate occasion to say anything more about that. I have received correspondence from Mr Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Territory, relating to this and offering me the services of departmental officers, in particular Mr Sturgess, the Queensland barrister who has been most closely associated with the drafting of this, and that is certainly an offer I will take up, one way or the other, before going public again on this matter. I think that is only fair to all concerned. I cannot put a precise time limit on it. I know the degree of anxiety this is causing in the Territory and it is certainly a matter that I regard as demanding attention on my part with a degree of urgency and it will be a matter of days rather than weeks, but just when I cannot say at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the matter raised by Senator Reid in regard to funding cuts in the particular scheme for the disabled to which she referred, I will draw that matter to the attention of the appropriate Minister. I am never quite sure, with the Australian Capital Territory, just who the Minister is-whether it is the functional Minister or the geographical Minister or some combination of the two- but I will endeavour to secure a response for her at the earliest possible date.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 7 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Science and Technology instruct the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation on how to allocate its Budget funds.
(2) Did this instruction take the form of a direction; if so; (a) under what power was it given; and (b) was it made known to the Parliament by the Minister; and, if not, why not.
(3) What form did the instruction take if it was not in the form of a direction and upon what basis did the Minister interfere with this statutory authority.
(4) In what manner are CSIRO's Budget funds for 1983-84 to be allocated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) On 28 July 1983 the Minister for Science and Technology gave a formal direction to CSIRO and on 16 August he made a formal request by letter about the expenditure of funds.

(a) The direction was given by the Minister for Science and Technology in the exercise of his powers as Minister having portfolio responsibility for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to give a direction to the Executive, under Section 13 of the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 .
(b) This direction will be reported to the Parliament in CSIRO's 1983-84 annual report in accordance with the requirement of Section 57 of the Science and Industry Research Act 1949.
The direction has not been formally advised to the Parliament; it has been widely publicised by way of a Budget media release.

(3) The formal request of 16 August 1983 was made by letter directed to the Chairman of CSIRO. It requested CSIRO to ensure that $23.4m was allocated to a package of programs in specific key technology areas. The request was made by the Minister in the exercise of his powers as set out in the answer to 2 (a).

(4) On the passage of the Appropriation bills, C.S.I.R.O.'s budget appropriation will be expended in accordance with estimates of expenditure approved by the Minister for Science and Technology under Section 49 of the Science and Industry Research Act 1949. These estimates will accord with the explanatory notes provided by C.S.I.R.O. to assist the Senate in its examination of the Organisation's estimates.
